He is the chairman and founder of [[Abdullah AlOthaim Markets|Abdullah Al-Othaim Markets]], one of the Middle East's largest companies.<ref>[http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/lists/people/pname/othaim-markets/pid/77401/ TOP 100 COMPANIES IN THE KSA 2016]،Forbes Magazine.</ref><ref>[http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/lists/people/pname/othaim-markets/pid/77260/ THE TOP 200 COMPANIES IN THE ARAB WORLD 2016]،Forbes Magazine.</ref> He is also the chairman of Abdullah Al Othaim Investment and Real Estate Development company.
He was the chairman of the General Council for [[Al-Qassim Region|Qassim]] Chamber of Commerce. In 2015 [[Forbes]] listed Abdullah Al-Othaim as the 61st richest man in the [[Arab world]], with an estimated net worth of US$445.47 Million.<ref>[http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/lists/people/pname/abdullah-saleh-al-othaim-family/pid/83786/ THE WORLD RICHEST ARABS 2015]،Forbes Magazine.</ref>Abdullah Al-Othaim among 500 Most Powerful Muslims List in Islamica Magazine.<ref>[http://www.al-jazirah.com/2015/20151118/mt1.htm 500 Most Powerful Muslims List in Islamica Magazine]، AL-jazirah post، In 18 November 2015.</ref>
==Background and career==
Abdullah Al-Othaim has over 37 years of operational and management experience. Founded in 1980, [[Abdullah Al-Othaim Markets]] is a publicly traded company which was listed on [[Tadawul]] (the Saudi Stock Exchange) in 2008. Abdullah Al-Othaim Markets is one of the [[Arab world]]'s most successful and diversified business organizations, highly respected in the field of investments and recognized as an elite player in the [[Persian Gulf]] region. He was appointed a board member of [[Saudi Industrial Property Authority]]. In 2015 he was appointed a board member of Saudi Credit and Saving Bank.<ref>[https://books.google.com.sa/books?redir_esc=y&hl=ar&id=59sdAQAAMAAJ&dq=Saleh+Othaim D and B Principal International Businesses – Dun & Bradstreet, 2009 – Page 112]</ref>

'''Alan Ling Sie Kiong''' ({{zh|s=林思健|hp=Lín Sījiàn}}; born 19 February 1983) is a Malaysian lawyer and politician. He is currently holding office of DAP Sarawak Secretary and Pakatan Harapan Sarawak Secretary.
Ling was appointed and sworn in as Senator in the Upper House [[Dewan Negara]] of [[Parliament of Malaysia]] on 27 August 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2018/08/28/12-pakatan-and-warisan-members-made-senators/|title=12 Pakatan and Warisan members made senators |date=28 August 2018 |work=|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|language=|accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>
He spent his childhood in Nanga Medamit, Limbang, Sarawak where his parents started their first business venture by operating a small grocery shops next to a river in the rural area.{{citation needed|reason=this is very personal information and needs a reliable source|date=December 2015}}
Ling received his primary education in SRB Chung Hua Limbang, North School Miri and secondary school in SMK St. Joseph Miri. He is a Christian.
Ling graduated from the [[University of Sheffield]] with a [[Bachelor of Laws]] honours degree. He is an Advocate & Solicitor of the [[High Court in Malaya]] and [[High Court in Sabah and Sarawak]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Rolls (no. 1132)|url=http://sarawak-advocates.org.my/index.php/rolls-a-directories/rolls |publisher=Advocates' Association of Sarawak |accessdate=}}</ref>
Ling became the managing partner of an established law firm Suhaili & Ling Advocates in [[Miri, Malaysia|Miri]] at the age of 27.<ref>{{cite web |title=Suhaili & Ling Advocates. (Miri) He has particular interest in criminal law and was a pupil to the late YB Karpal Singh.
|url=http://sarawak-advocates.org.my/index.php/rolls-a-directories/legal-firms/423-suhaili-a-bong-advocates-miri |publisher=Advocates' Association of Sarawak |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref>
He is also the partner of Tee, Liew & Co which is situated in Petaling Jaya and Johor Bahru in West Malaysia.
Besides legal qualification, he is a licensed auctioneer, company secretary and also actively involved in the business field since his university time.
During his stay in United Kingdom, he was the President of [[Malaysian Law Students Union in the United Kingdom and Eire]] (KPUM) for the term 2004/2005.<ref>http://www.kpum.org/ourteam/past-committees/</ref>
He also held the post of President for MCA Club United Kingdom for the term 2005/2006.
At the age of 25 in 2008, he successfully obtained license from [[Bank Negara Malaysia]] to operate remittance business in partnership with [[Western Union]], it is one of the pioneers non-bank remittance operators in Malaysia. In 2015, he sold the company operation to another remittance operator.
Ling joined DAP in 2011 and had been elected Honourable Member of the [[Sarawak State Legislative Assembly]] for [[Piasau]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Y.B. Encik Alan Ling Sie Kiong |url=http://www.dun.sarawak.gov.my/modules/web/pages.php?mod=webpage&sub=page&id=102}}</ref> He won the seat at the age of 28 by upsetting the then Sarawak Deputy Chief Minister cum Sarawak United People's Party President Tan Sri Dr [[George Chan Hong Nam]] in the [[Sarawak state election, 2011|2011 state election]]. He defeated Chan by a 1,590-vote majority.<ref>{{cite web|title=N.63 Piasau |url=http://semak.spr.gov.my/dunsarawak/module/5_KeputusanDUNAWAMVIEW.php?kod=21963 |publisher=[[Election Commission of Malaysia]] |accessdate=6 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722025017/http://semak.spr.gov.my/dunsarawak/module/5_KeputusanDUNAWAMVIEW.php?kod=21963 |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Ling is a charismatic young politician and has been widely known for his excellent oratory skill, down to earth approach and dedication towards his constituents. He has a community centre within his constituency.
He has been appointed honourable/legal advisors to several associations in Miri and is a well-known lawyer in Miri.
He seek for re-election in 2016 Sarawak State Election but lost to BN SUPP candidate. His focus is now on his legal practice, business interest and party works.

[[New Zealand Reform Party|Reform]] (1925–1928) |otherparty = |spouse = |partner = |relations = |children = |residence = |alma_mater = |occupation = |profession = |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = |signature = |signature_alt= }} '''Lt. Colonel Allan (Allen) Bell''' (14 February 1870 – 15 October 1936) was a New Zealand Member of Parliament for the [[Bay of Islands]] in [[Northland Region|Northland]]. == Early life == Bell was born at [[Southbridge, New Zealand]] on 14 February 1870. He was the son of Allen and Mary, farmers in the area. He worked as a bushman and a farmer. In 1895, Bell travelled to southern Africa and served with the British armed forces that in 1896 [[Second Matabele War|suppressed a rising]] by the Matabele ([[Northern Ndebele people|Ndebele]]) people. He then saw active service with the [[Rhodesia Regiment]] during the [[Second Boer War|South African (Boer) War]]. Bell was discharged on 31 January 1900 and returned to [[Taranaki]]. On 29 January 1902 he married James Helen Shaw Lambie at [[Pihama]]. They bought land at [[Te Rapa]], north of Hamilton. Their daughter Elaline was born there on 6 July 1904. ==Hamilton and the Waikato== Bell was a member of the [[Waipa District|Waipa]] County Council and the [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]] Borough Council. He was the founder of the Waikato Agricultural and Pastoral (A & P) Association and the first director of the [[Waikato]] Dairy Company in 1912.{{sfn|Scholefield|1940|p=56}} As a conservative, Bell stood for the {{NZ electorate link|Waikato}} electorate at the [[New Zealand general election, 1908|1908 general election]] for the [[Opposition (parliamentary)|opposition]], but lost to the incumbent from the [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal Party]], [[Henry Greenslade]].{{sfn|AtoJs 1908 election|1909|p=6}} At the [[New Zealand general election, 1911|1911 general election]] Bell stood as an unofficial [[New Zealand Reform Party|Reform Party]] candidate in the newly formed [[Raglan (New Zealand electorate)|Raglan]] electorate; the official Reform Party candidate was [[Richard Bollard]].{{cite news|title=Next Thursday's Poll|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NZH19111204.2.30|accessdate=26 April 2015|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|volume=XLVIII|issue=14854|date=4 December 1911|page=7}} Bell came into conflict with the party's executive over liquor licensing issues, as "it was used not for the purpose of raising the status of politics, but in the interest of the liquor party."{{cite news|title=The Elections|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=WT19111206.2.12|accessdate=26 April 2015|work=[[Waikato Times]]|issue=12149|date=6 December 1911|page=4}} During the campaign Bell created controversy when he advocated the abolition of the [[Monarchy of New Zealand|monarchy]], and the creation of a [[Republicanism in New Zealand|New Zealand republic]].{{cite news |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=PBH19111118.2.28 |title=A "Reform" Candidate Favors A Republic |date=18 November 1911 |work=[[Poverty Bay Herald]] |agency=Press Association |accessdate=20 July 2011}} He also argued for the abolition of [[New Zealand Legislative Council|New Zealand's upper house]] and Britain's [[House of Lords]]. As a result of his comments, the Reform Party disendorsed Bell as their candidate.{{cite news |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NA19111202.2.20.7.4 |title=Not authorised |work=[[The Northern Advocate]] |date=2 December 1911 |page=5}} The armed forces considered that Bell had broken his [[Oath of Allegiance (New Zealand)|Oath of Allegiance]] as an Officer (Lieutenant Colonel). Under pressure, he reluctantly resigned his commission in January 1912.{{DNZB|Crawford|J. A. B.|3B24|Bell, Allen|8 November 2014}} ==Legion of Frontiersmen== In 1911, Bell joined the New Zealand Command of the [[Legion of Frontiersmen]] and after his discharge from the army went on to devote much of his time and energy into the promoting and expanding the Legion. Bell was appointed as the Legion's Commandant for Auckland with the rank of Colonel. He retained and used this Legion of Frontiersmen rank for the rest of his life.{{cite web|url=http://frontiersmen.homestead.com/famous.html|title=The Famous and the Infamous members of the Legion of frontiersmen|publisher=Legion of Frontiersmen New Zealand Command|accessdate=8 August 2011}} In 1912, Bell journeyed to [[Dargaville]] and met with local men Dick Long, Andy Knudson and one other met in the Central Hotel in [[Dargaville]] one winter's night and formed the Northern Wairoa (Mounted Rifles) Squadron of the Legion.{{cite web |url=http://www.dargaville.co.nz/Feature.cfm?WPID=101 |title=Dargaville – History |accessdate=8 August 2011 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110724192505/http://www.dargaville.co.nz/Feature.cfm?WPID=101| archivedate= 24 July 2011 | deadurl= no}} In 1913, as Commandant of the Auckland District Bell convened and chaired a meeting of the Legion in the "Hall of Commerce" for the purpose of considering the viability of setting up a Dominion Executive of the Legion, the election of a Commandant for the North Island and other matters. A ballot was taken by A Squadron's secretary, Frontiersman Thomas E. Whitton, which showed a large majority in favour of a Dominion Executive, a five shilling annual levy for its support, and election of Colonel Bell as the North Island Commandant of the Legion. Captain Forbes-Eadie LOF moved that the current Auckland Executive be disbanded and that Colonel Bell's new executive take over. This was unanimously approved. At the conclusion of the meeting Colonel Bell referred to the great loss sustained by the Defence Forces by the very recent death of Mrs Brewis (of Hamilton), who was the first woman in New Zealand to assist in organising the universal military training movement. ==Northland== In 1914, three Bell brothers (Allen, Leonard and Walter) bought land in what is today [[Kaitaia]]. He was an enthusiastic promoter of the area north of Auckland, and did much lobbying for making the area accessible via roads and bridges. He acted as a land agent and was a newspaper editor, first writing for the ''Northern Age'' and then founding the ''Northlander''. Bell was a supporter of the government's scheme of draining land in the Kaitaia area, and as an owner of swampy land and a land agent, he personally benefited from the initiative. ==Member of Parliament== {{NZ parlbox header|nolist = true}} {{NZ parlbox |start={{NZ election link year|1922}} |end=1925 |term=21st |electorate={{NZ electorate link|Bay of Islands}} |party=Independent politician 2015|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|volume=LIX|issue=18198|date=18 September 1922|page=6}} He stood for opposition interests (at the time, [[William Massey]]'s [[Reform Government of New Zealand|Reform government]] was in power) and was variously described as an Independent or [[Independent Liberal]].{{sfn|Wood|1996|pp=101, 114}}{{cite news|title=General Election |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NZH19221024.2.110 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |volume=LIX |issue=18229 |date=24 October 1922 |page=9}}{{cite news |title=The General Election |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=CHP19221114.2.72 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |work=[[The Press]] |volume=LVIII |issue=17611 |date=14 November 1922 |page=9}} He won against the incumbent of the Reform Party, [[Vernon Reed]].{{cite book |first1=J. |last1=Hislop |title=The General Election, 1922 |year=1923 |publisher=Government Printer |url= http://atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&d=AJHR1923-I-II.2.2.5.36 |page=1 |accessdate=24 April 2015}} In [[New Zealand general election, 1925|1925]], Bell successfully stood for the Reform Party,{{sfn|Wilson|1985|p=183}} but was defeated by [[Harold Rushworth]] of the [[Country Party (New Zealand)|Country Party]] in [[New Zealand general election, 1928|1928]].{{sfn|Wilson|1985|pp=183, 232}} The election result was declared void, but in the subsequent [[Bay of Islands by-election, 1929|1929 by-election]] Rushworth was again elected.{{sfn|Wilson|1985|p=232}} ==Death== Bell retired in Paua on the [[Parengarenga Harbour]]. Member of the [[European Club Association]] (ECA) and appointed to join the [[UEFA#UEFA Executive Committee|UEFA Executive Committee]] since 2015. He is a member of the famous industrialist [[Agnelli family]]. He is also a board member of [[FIAT]] and [[Exor (company)|Exor]].
==Early life== Agnelli is the son of late Juventus F.C. chairman and [[Italian Senate|senator]] of the [[Italian Republic]] [[Umberto Agnelli]], [[chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Fiat]] from 1970–1976, and Donna Allegra [[Caracciolo]] di Castagneto, first cousin of [[Marella Agnelli]], born Donna Marella Caracciolo di Castagneto and daughter of Filippo Caracciolo, 8th Prince di Castagneto, 3rd Duke di Melito, and a hereditary [[Patrician (post-Roman Europe)|Patrician]] of Naples (1903-1965). Marella, widow of Agnelli's uncle [[Gianni Agnelli|Gianni]], and Allegra and, therefore, Andrea, are both members of and old [[Naples|Neapolitan]] [[Nobility|noble]] family that hold the titles of Prince of Castagneto and Duke of Melito, among others.
Andrea was the last male member of the family to carry the [[Agnelli]] surname until the birth of his son Giacomo. He studied at [[St Clare's, Oxford|St Clare's]] in [[Oxford]], England and then at [[Bocconi University]] in [[Milan]].
==Career== After university, Agnelli started his career in the business world in England and France at companies including [[Iveco]] and [[Auchan|Auchan Hypermarché]]. He also spent several years in [[Switzerland]] working in [[marketing]] and development for [[Ferrari]] Idea S.A. and [[Lausanne]]-based [[Philip Morris International]].
===Juventus F.C.=== In May 2010 he was appointed Chairman of the board of directors of [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] by his first cousin [[John Elkann]], becoming the fourth member of the [[Agnelli family]] to run the football club after his father, his uncle and his grandfather.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lastampa.it/sport/cmsSezioni/quijuve/201004articoli/26580girata.asp |title=Juve, John Elkann disegna il futuro "Andrea Agnelli sarà il presidente" |language=Italian |trans-title=Juve, John Elkann marks the future: "Andrea Agnelli will be the chairman" |publisher=[[La Stampa]] |date=28 April 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130065347/http://www.lastampa.it/sport/cmsSezioni/quijuve/201004articoli/26580girata.asp |archivedate=30 January 2012 }}</ref> Elkann had come under criticism from Juventus fans for the club's poor results during the [[2009–10 Serie A|2009–10 season]] and many [[Juventus Ultras|ultras]] saw Agnelli as the "rightful" heir due to his family's long-time association with the club. Despite entering the job during a period when the club was still dealing with the aftermath of the infamous ''[[Calciopoli]]'' scandal, he is credited with overseeing the club's transition into the [[Juventus Stadium|new stadium]] and balancing their finances in wake of the [[Late-2000s recession in Europe#Italy|ongoing recession]] ravaging Italy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stadio, Vinovo, marchio e rosa: la Juve vale di più|url=http://www.tuttosport.com/calcio/serie_a/juventus/2011/10/10-148539/Stadio,+Vinovo,+marchio+e+rosa%3A+la+Juve+vale+di+pi%C3%B9|publisher=[[Tuttosport]]|date=10 October 2011|language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=La Juventus e il nuovo stadio, "29" scudetti nello spogliatoio|url=http://www.repubblica.it/rubriche/spycalcio/2011/10/05/news/la_juventus_e_il_nuovo_stadio-22724162/|publisher=[[La Repubblica]]|date=5 October 2011|language=Italian}}</ref> One of his first acts as new chairman was to appoint [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]] duo [[Giuseppe Marotta]] as Director of Sport and [[Luigi Delneri]] as new coach.
On 22 May 2011, Agnelli appointed former captain and fan favourite [[Antonio Conte]] as the new manager of Juventus, replacing Delneri. The same season Juventus won the first ''[[scudetto]]'' undefeated under Agnelli.<ref>{{cite news|title=Conte replaces Del Neri at Juventus|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/924796/antonio-conte-to-replace-lugi-del-neri-at-juventus?cc=5901|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=13 May 2011}}</ref> Since then, Juventus won seven ''scudetti'' in a row as of [[2017–18 Serie A|2017–18]], a record in [[Serie A]], including four [[Coppa Italia]] titles in a row since [[2014–15 Coppa Italia|2014–15]].
On 8 September 2015, Agnelli was re-elected as a member of the [[European Club Association]](ECA) Executive Board, a position he has held since 2012. He was also appointed by the ECA Executive Board to join the [[UEFA#UEFA Executive Committee|UEFA Executive Committee]] on behalf of ECA, where he will represent the 220 ECA member clubs alongside re-elected ECA chairman [[Karl-Heinz Rummenigge]] for the next two years 2015-17.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecaeurope.com/news/eca-member-clubs-elect-new-executive-board/|title=ECA Member Clubs elect new Executive Board|publisher=ecaeurope.com|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.juventus.com/en/news/news/2015/rummenigge-and-agnelli-enter-uefa-executive-committee-.php|title=Rummenigge and Agnelli enter UEFA Executive Committee|publisher=juventus.com|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
===Legal troubles=== In 2014, some of Juventus' senior management, including Agnelli, were investigated by the [[Public prosecutor's office]] of Turin on the management of [[tickets (admission)|tickets]] at the Juventus Stadium,<ref name="ANSA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/sport/calcio/2017/03/07/procura-figc-contatto-tra-agnelli-e-boss-per-gestione-biglietti_be0314bd-f4f5-4923-baaf-5c1b4a6a13fd.html|title=Procura Figc, contatto tra Agnelli e boss per gestione biglietti Juventus|date=7 March 2017|language=Italian}}</ref> about the alleged infiltration of the [['Ndrangheta]] in the commercial management of the company's tickets;<ref>{{cite web|author=Massimiliano Peggio|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2017/05/15/cronaca/agnelli-in-tribunale-mai-ricevuto-pressioni-sui-biglietti-dalla-criminalit-organizzata-87YcYnyroPPts26kiLeBZJ/pagina.html|title=Agnelli in tribunale: "Mai ricevuto pressioni sui biglietti dalla criminalità organizzata"|date=15 May 2017|language=Italian}}</ref> the public ministers of Turin did not formalize criminal charges against Juventus or its members,<ref name="ANSA"/> closing the investigation three years later with a filing request as there were no links between the Juventus management and the groups and/or individual people involved in [[organized crime]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Marco Bellinazzo|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/notizie/2017-03-07/rapporti-la-cosca-bellocco-pesce-che-cosa-rischia-juve-170230.shtml|title=Pecoraro smentisce: irresponsabile attribuirmi frasi su Juve e cosche|date=7 March 2017}}</ref> On 18 March 2017, following the opening of a lawsuit by a prosecutor from the Turin Public Prosecutor's Office, Agnelli was referred by the [[FIGC]]'s Attorney General along with three other club executives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/it/204/2536768/2017/03/News.shtml|title=Deferiti la Juventus, il Presidente Andrea Agnelli e altri 3 dirigenti bianconeri|date=18 March 2017|language=Italian}}</ref> The following 15 September, the FIGC reformulated its allegations, excluding a presumed Mafia association from the members of the incriminated club after the prosecutor Giuseppe Pecoraro's intervention to the [[Antimafia Commission]] in April;<ref>{{cite web|author=Commissione parlamentare antimafia|url=http://www.radioradicale.it/scheda/505027/commissione-parlamentare-di-inchiesta-sul-fenomeno-delle-mafie-e-sulle-altre|title=Commissione parlamentare di inchiesta sul fenomeno delle mafie e sulle altre associazioni criminali, anche straniere|publisher=Radio Radicale|date=5 April 2017|language=Italian}}</ref> the prosecutor asked for sanctions for the meetings of Agnelli with ultra groups and the sale of the tickets by the rest of the offenders beyond the limit allowed per person (thus favouring [[ticket resale|ticket scalping]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/it/204/2539131/2017/09/News.shtml|title=Deferimento Juventus: le richieste della Procura Federale|date=15 September 2017|language=Italian}}</ref> On 25 September, Agnelli was banned for one year and fined €20,000, while Juventus were fined €300,000 for selling tickets to ultras, however alleged connections to organized crime were not present in the ruling.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.football-italia.net/110402/official-agnelli-banned-year|title=Official: Agnelli banned for a year|publisher=Football Italia|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> On 18 December, Agnelli's ban was lifted, however he was required to pay a €100,000 fine, while the fine against Juventus doubled to €600,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.football-italia.net/114485/official-agnelli-ban-revoked|title=Official: Agnelli ban revoked, but...|publisher=Football Italia|date=18 December 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== On 27 August 2005 he married Emma Winter in a Roman Catholic ceremony in [[Villar Perosa]] ([[Piedmont]], [[Italy]]) at the church of San Pietro in Vincoli. The wedding reception was held at Villa Agnelli, [[Marella Agnelli|Donna Marella Agnelli]]'s estate in [[Villar Perosa]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Il sì di Andrea e Emma Festa a Villar Perosa per il giovane Agnelli |url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2005/agosto/28/Andrea_Emma_Festa_Villar_Perosa_co_9_050828049.shtml|work=Corriere della Sera |date=28 August 2005 |accessdate=28 September 2013 |language=Italian}}</ref> The couple has two children: Baya Agnelli (born on 24 May 2005 in [[Turin]])<ref>{{cite news |title=E' nata Baya Agnelli figlia di Andrea |url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2005/maggio/26/nata_Baya_Agnelli_figlia_Andrea_co_9_050526037.shtml|work= Corriere della Sera |date=26 May 2005 |accessdate=28 September 2013 |language=Italian}}</ref> and Giacomo Dai Agnelli (born 16 December 2011 in [[Turin]]).<ref>{{cite news |title=Andrea Agnelli di nuovo papà é nato Giacomo Dai |url=http://torino.repubblica.it/cronaca/2011/12/16/news/andrea_agnelli_di_nuovo_pap_nato_giacomo_dai-26721316/|work=La Repubblica |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=28 September 2013 |language=Italian}}</ref>

[[File:Flag of Hungary 1940.svg|23px]] [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)|Kingdom of Hungary]] |branch = |serviceyears =1893–1921 |rank =[[General (Germany)|Generalmajor]]{{cite news|author= |title=Anton Lehar gestorben |newspaper=[[Hamburger Abendblatt]] |language=German |date=November 16, 1962 |url=http://archiv.abendblatt.de/ha/1962/pdf/19621116.pdf/ASV_HAB_19621116_HA_002.pdf }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |servicenumber = |unit = |commands = |battles = |battles_label = |awards =*[[Military Merit Medal (Austria-Hungary)]] *Officers' cross of the [[Order of the Star of Romania]] *4th class of the Ottoman Osmanie Order{{cite web|url=http://www.austro-hungarian-army.co.uk/biog/leharant.htm|title=Anton Freiherr von Lehár|author=|accessdate=14 March 2008}} *Orden der Eisernen Krone 3.Klasse mit Kriegsdekoration{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | page =13 | language =German}} *[[Iron Cross]] 2nd Class *Militärverdienstkreuz III.Klasse mit Kriegsdekoration und Schwertern{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | page =15 | language =German}} *Goldene Tapferkeitsmedaille{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | page =17 | language =German}} *[[Knight's Cross]] of the [[Military Order of Maria Theresa]] |spouse = |relations = |laterwork = |signature = |website = }} '''Anton Freiherr von Lehár''' (born '''Antal Lehár'''; 21 February 1876 – 12 November 1962; known sometimes as ''Baron Antal Lehár'') was an Hungarian [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]], who reached the pinnacle of his service after [[World War I]] when he supported the former Emperor [[Charles I of Austria's attempts to retake the throne of Hungary]]. His brother was composer [[Franz Lehár]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wien.gv.at/rk/historisch/1948/oktober.html|title=Wien 1948 – Berichte vom Oktober 1948: Bürgermeister Körner zum Tode Franz Lehars|author=Stadt Wien|date=26 October 1948|accessdate=4 January 2009|language =German}} [[File:Freiherr von Lehár (1918) – Gerd Hruška.png|thumb|upright|Lehár's arms as a baron, 1918.]] ==Early life== Lehár was born in [[Sopron]], [[Austria-Hungary]], as the younger son of a [[conducting|bandmaster]] in the [[Regiment|Infantry Regiment]] No. 50 of the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]]. He attended schools in Pressburg (Pozsony, today's [[Bratislava]]), [[Prague]] and Vienna.{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | page =59 | language =German}} He entered cadet school in Vienna to become a professional officer, finishing in 1893 top of his class. Following a posting to his father's regiment, he was promoted [[Second Lieutenant|Leutnant]] in 1894 and [[Oberleutnant]] in 1898. Between 1897 and 1899 Lehár attended the ''"[[Kriegsschule (Austria)|Kriegsschule]]'' (war college) in Vienna, after which he was attached to the general staff and served in a number of training positions until [[World War I]]. ==World War I== Following the outbreak of World War I, Lehár, now with the rank of [[Major]], was put in command of the 2nd [[battalion]] of the [[Military of Hungary|Honvéd]]-[[Landsturm]] Infantry Regiment No. 13, which he led in September 1914 during battles at [[Chodel]] south of [[Lublin]]. His battalion was part of the Army group "Kummer" and served next to the unit of [[Viktor Dankl von Krasnik|General Viktor Dankl]].{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | page =12 | language =German}} For his conduct there, Lehár would later be decorated with the [[Knight's Cross]] of the [[Military Order of Maria Theresa]] (see below). While still fighting near Lublin, Lehár was severely wounded. After leaving hospital he was reassigned to the War ministry in Vienna and in September 1915 he served in the Tyrolean Defence Command. Following promotion to [[Lieutenant Colonel|Oberstleutnant]] in September 1915, Lehár returned to fighting, this time on the Italian front. There he commanded the'' Heeresgruppe "Lehar"'' in the Etschtal-Rovereto sector of the Italian front, which consisted of Tyrolese ''[[Standschützen]]'' and [[Bosniaks]].{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | page =14 | language =German}} In June 1916 he was transferred back to the technical Military committee and became head of the department for infantry and cavalry weapons. Assignments to the Eastern front and to the office of [[Hermann Kövess von Kövessháza]] followed. Later he was transferred to the newly raised Infantry Regiment 106 and commanded this unit in the battles on the Piave. He served in the Infantry Regiment 106 until the end of the war.{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | pages =16–18 | language =German}} In May 1918 he was promoted to [[Colonel|Oberst]] and received the Golden Bravery Medal for Officers. In August 1918 Lehár was decorated with the Knight's Cross of the Military Order of Maria Theresa in recognition of his services during the battles at Chodel south of Lublin in September 1914. In accordance with the statutes of this order, Lehár became a [[baron]] in his country's nobility and was since styled "[[Freiherr]] von Lehár", while his brother [[Franz Lehár|Franz]] remained a commoner. At the conclusion of hostilities of World War I, Lehár was able to move his regiment, without any casualties or desertion, back to [[Szombathely]]. ==Hungary== After the dissolution of the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]], Oberst Anton Freiherr von Lehár decided to remain in Hungary and to fight again for the monarchy, in several roles and at various theatres of war. He played an important role in the counterrevolution in Hungary.{{cite book |author=Paul Lendvai | title =Die Ungarn – Ein Jahrtausend Sieger in Niederlagen | publisher = C.Bertelsmann | year =1999 | location =Munich | page =426 | language =German}}{{cite book | author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | pages =28–32 | language =German}} In August 1919 he became the [[Commander|military commander]] of Western Hungary and was promoted to [[Major General]] by [[Regent]] [[Miklós Horthy]]. When the former King [[Charles I of Austria|King Charles IV]] tried to [[Charles I of Austria's attempts to retake the throne of Hungary|return to the Hungarian throne]], Lehár joined his troops, but the mission failed.{{cite web|url=http://catholicism.org/karl-hapsburg.html|title=Ven. Emperor Karl I of Austria and Empress Zita|author=Gary Potter| accessdate=4 January 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.koel-starhemberg.at/das-erzhaus/restaurationsversuche.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706092958/http://www.koel-starhemberg.at/das-erzhaus/restaurationsversuche.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 July 2011 |title=Restaurationsversuche |author=Peter Broucek |accessdate=4 January 2009 |language=German }}{{cite web|url=http://www.paneuropa-vorarlberg.at/Kaiser%20Karl.doc |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706093818/http://www.paneuropa-vorarlberg.at/Kaiser%20Karl.doc |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 July 2011 |title=Kaiser Karl – ein Seliger |author=Erwin Bader |accessdate=4 January 2009 |language=German |format=doc }}{{cite news| author= |title = Die "Revision" versank in Blut und Tränen| newspaper =Der Standard|language = German|date=25 May 2001|url=http://derstandard.at/?url=/?id=592791}}{{cite book |author=Paul Lendvai | title =Die Ungarn – Ein Jahrtausend Sieger in Niederlagen | publisher = C. Bertelsmann | year =1999 | location =Munich | page =425 | language =German}} While the former monarch was transported into exile, Lehár escaped from Hungary and fled through [[Czechoslovakia]] to [[Germany]] where he hid with friends of his brother's. ==Life as a businessman== When the political turmoil had calmed down, Anton's brother Franz Lehár organized for the former general a job as director of the ''Society of Authors, Composers and Music Publishers'' in Berlin in 1926. With the rise of the [[Nazi Party|National Socialist Party]], Freiherr von Lehár was, as a dedicated Austrian-Hungarian monarchist, soon considered suspect. When the National Socialists assumed power in 1933 (''[[Machtergreifung]]''), he had to leave Berlin.{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | pages =19 | language =German}} Back in Vienna, Lehár founded the ''Chodel Music Publishing Company'', but after it did not prosper, he decided to hand over the business to his brother in 1935. He then moved to the countryside, becoming a farmer in [[Theresienfeld]] near [[Wiener Neustadt]] in [[Lower Austria]]. When Germany occupied Austria in March 1938 (''[[Anschluss]]''), Lehár was ordered to move to Vienna, where the [[Gestapo]] could keep a closer eye on him and his wife for much of [[World War II]].{{cite book |author=Anton Lehar |author2=Peter Broucek | title =Erinnerungen: Gegenrevolution und Restaurationsversuche in Ungarn 1918–1921 | publisher = Verlag für Geschichte und Politik | year =1973 | location =Vienna | pages =19–21 | language =German}} After Franz Lehár's death in October 1948, the former general became the administrator of his estate and spent the rest of his life guarding the rights and promoting the popularity of his brother's music. Anton Freiherr von Lehár died in Vienna in 1962, aged 86. == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Commons category-inline|Anton Lehár}} {{Franz Lehár|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lehar, Anton}} [[Category:1876 births]] [[Category:1962 deaths]] [[Category:People from Sopron]] [[Category:Austro-Hungarian military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Austro-Hungarian businesspeople]] [[Category:Hungarian monarchists]] [[Category:Royalty and nobility of Austria-Hungary]] [[Category:Hungarian nobility]] [[Category:Hungarian Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Hungarian-German people]]

[[The Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | spouse = | nationality = [[Spanish people|Spanish]] | religion= | children = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Carlos Solchaga Catalán''' (born 1944) is a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] economist, businessman and politician, who served in different capacities at various Spanish cabinets. ==Early life and education== Solchaga was born in [[Tafalla]] in 1944.{{cite web|title=Carlos Solchaga|url=http://www.biografiasyvidas.com/biografia/s/solchaga.htm|work=Biografias y Vidas|accessdate=7 July 2013}} He holds a bachelor's degree in economics and business studies which he obtained from Madrid’s [[Complutense University of Madrid|Complutense University]] in 1966.{{cite web|title=Directors |url=http://www.solchagarecio.es/eng/curriculum01.php?id=7 |work=Solchaga Recio |accessdate=7 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608095113/http://solchagarecio.es/eng/curriculum01.php?id=7 |archivedate=8 June 2013 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|title=José Luis Sampedro: Economist who became an inspiration for Spain's anti-austerity movement|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/jos-luis-sampedro-economist-who-became-an-inspiration-for-spains-antiausterity-movement-8636614.html|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=The Independent|date=29 May 2013}} He received a master's degree from [[The Massachusetts Institute of Technology|the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)]] in 1971. ==Career== Solchaga began his career at [[Bank of Spain|the Bank of Spain]].{{cite book|author=John Williamson|title=The Political Economy of Policy Reform|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cm-3mnvjEl8C&pg=PA130|accessdate=7 July 2013|date=January 1994|publisher=Peterson Institute|isbn=978-0-88132-195-1|page=130}} He was the economic studies manager and advisor at Banco de Vizcaya from 1976 to 1979. Then he served as a minister for trade of the Basque general council of Spain from 1979 to 1980. He was the member of [[Spanish Parliament|the Spanish Parliament]] from 1980 to 1995, representing [[Navarre (Spanish Congress Electoral District)|Navarre Province]], being part of [[Socialist Party (Spain)|the Socialist Party]]. He was one of the party officials who developed neo-liberal economic program{{cite book|author=Omar G. Encarnación|title=Spanish Politics: Democracy After Dictatorship|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F1wWKJVaZeIC&pg=PA60|accessdate=7 July 2013|date=8 July 2008|publisher=Polity|isbn=978-0-7456-3992-5|page=60}} and was among right-wing leaders of the party.{{cite book|author=Paul Heywood|title=Politics and Policy in Democratic Spain: No Longer Different?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VUAAAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA164|accessdate=15 January 2014|date=5 November 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-23142-2|page=164}} His first ministerial post was the minister for industry and energy,Edward Schumacher [https://www.nytimes.com/1985/07/05/world/spain-s-leader-drops-top-aides-in-a-big-shuffle.html Spain's leader drops top aides in a big shuffle] ''The New York Times'' 5 July 1985 Retrieved 19 October 2013 which he held from 1982 to 1985 in the first cabinet of [[Felipe Gonzalez Marquez]].{{cite journal|title=A new energy model for Spain |journal=IDEAS Foundation |date=20 May 2009 |url=http://www.fundacionideas.es/sites/default/files/pdf/Report_energy_ingles_web.pdf |accessdate=7 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705063626/http://fundacionideas.es/sites/default/files/pdf/Report_energy_ingles_web.pdf |archivedate=5 July 2012 |df=dmy }} In a reshuffle of July 1985, From 2012 to 2017, she was Under Secretary for the [[Secretary for the Environment|Environment]] in the government of [[CY Leung]].{{cite web|url=http://www.enb.gov.hk/en/about_us/organisation/index.html|title=Organisation|accessdate=2012-11-05}}[https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/09/17/ex-environment-deputy-christine-loh-update-revise-book-communist-party-hong-kong/ Ex-environment deputy Christine Loh to update and revise book on Communist Party in Hong Kong], HKFP, by Kris Cheng, 17 Sept 2017 Until her appointment as Undersecretary for the Environment, Loh was CEO of Civic Exchange, the Hong Kong [[think tank]] that she co-founded in 2000. She was named "Woman of the Year for 2006" by ''Hong Kong Business''. She has worked in many areas, including law, business, politics, media and the [[non-profit sector]], but is best known as a leading voice in public policy in Hong Kong, particularly in promoting democracy and environmental protection. She has long been associated with the campaign to save Hong Kong's Harbour from excessive land reclamation and overdevelopment.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} In 2017, following the end of her official role, she is an adjunct professor in the Division of [[Sustainability and environmental management|Environment and Sustainability]] at the [[Hong Kong University of Science and Technology]], and is said to be revising her book ''Underground Front: The Chinese Communist Party in Hong Kong'', first published in 2010. ==Education and professional career== Loh attended [[St. Paul's Convent School]] in Causeway Bay, and later [[Island School]] in Mid-levels, Hong Kong. She then went to [[Bedford High School (Bedfordshire)|Bedford High School]] in the UK. She later attended the [[University of Hull]], [[City University of Hong Kong]] (Masters of Law in Chinese & Comparative Law) and the [[University of Hull]] (Doctor of Law, honoris causa) and was trained as a lawyer but she worked for 12 years as a commodities trader (1980–1991), rising to become managing director and later director of business development. Loh spent fourteen years in the commercial world, holding top regional posts in commodities trading at Philipp Brothers and [[Phibro]] Energy – the physical commodities trading arms of US multinational Salomon, Inc. (now Citicorp) — before joining a Hong Kong company (CIM Co.), where she headed the special projects division between 1992 and 1994. In April 2006, she was elected by shareholders of the [[Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing]] (HKEx) to be a director of the company. == Political career == Loh was appointed to the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|Legislative Council]] (LegCo) in 1992. In 1995 and 1998 she ran in two direct elections and won by large margins. She co-founded, in 1995, the [[Society for Protection of the Harbour]] and was responsible for creating and sponsoring the historic [[Protection of the Harbour Ordinance]].[http://www.cdeclips.com/en/hongkong/fullstory.html?id=75707 New talents to boost govt] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130118205228/http://www.cdeclips.com/en/hongkong/fullstory.html?id=75707 |date=18 January 2013 }}, China Daily, 13 Sept 2012 While part of the democratic camp in LegCo, she took a less confrontational approach than some, preferring to keep open lines of communication with the so-called pro-China camp. {{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} In 2000, she and Lisa Hopkinson co-founded a Hong Kong-based non-profit [[think tank]], [[Civic Exchange]], and once again entered the political spotlight, but outside of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|LegCo]]. '''Continuous accounting''' is an approach to managing the accounting cycle that can be the key to achieving a more strategic finance and accounting function in a corporation. It is designed to be a practical approach that addresses the tactical issues that prevent finance departments from being more strategic. Continuous accounting embraces three main principles:<ref>http://blog.ventanaresearch.com/2015/10/30/continuous-accounting-enables-a-strategic-finance-department</ref>
*The first is the need to automate mechanical, repetitive accounting processes in a continuous, end-to-end fashion. Managing processes in a controlled, end-to-end fashion improves efficiency and it ensures [[data integrity]]. Ensuring data integrity is crucial because the absence of data integrity is the root cause of a lot of time consuming work that departments perform that adds little value to the rest of the company.
*The second is optimizing the [[Accounting|accounting calendar]] by distributing workloads continuously and evenly over the accounting period<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.blackline.com/blog/continuous-accounting/what-is-continuous-accounting/|title=What Is Continuous Accounting? {{!}} BlackLine Magazine|date=2016-07-20|work=BlackLine Magazine|access-date=2017-05-11|language=en-US}}</ref> (the month, quarter or year) to [http://www.digitalistmag.com/finance/2017/02/17/what-is-continuous-accounting-04917410 eliminate bottlenecks and optimize when and in which order accounting tasks are performed].
*The third is establishing a culture of [[continuous improvement]] in managing the accounting cycle. A continuous improvement culture sets increasingly rigorous objectives, reviews performance to those objectives frequently and makes addressing performance shortcomings a departmental priority.
Continuous accounting requires the effective use of information (data) and technology (software) to automate accounting and finance processes in an end-to-end fashion. This doesn’t mean that every step is entirely hands-off but processes are designed to automate the execution of as many steps as is practical. It also involves automating all the hand-offs that take place between people in performing the process as well as any managing all administrative and approval steps that must take place. End-to-end automation has two objectives. One is to cut down on the time employees spend doing work that computers can do faster and more consistently. The second is to improve the quality of the data in a company’s financial records to ensure greater accuracy, consistency and control of financial data. In this respect, continuous accounting supports the [[Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission|COSO Framework]].
Automation improves data quality because eliminating human intervention in the handling of data substantially reduces the potential for errors in a well-controlled IT environment. Consequently, by design, end-to-end financial process automation strengthens financial controls and facilitates auditing. Spreadsheets and manual calculations create the need for time consuming reconciliations and checks to spot errors and identify their source.
An important design objective for end-to-end automation is to ensure that there is a single authoritative source for the data that’s used in accounting processes. Technology exists to ensures that even with multiple accounting and financial management systems and data stores, there’s no duplication of data that requires checks and reconciliations.
To second component of continuous accounting focuses on optimizing workloads. Increasingly, financial software gives companies greater flexibility. The classic accounting calendar with its monthly, quarterly and annual cycles developed over centuries as a practical approach to dealing with the limitations of the paper based systems and manual calculations. Their frequency represents a trade-off aimed at balancing efficiency and control: waiting until there are enough entries to justify performing the work, but not waiting too long to identify fraud, procedural issues and accounting errors. The monthly accounting close developed for many accounting tasks because a weekly cadence proved to be too short a period to be efficient while quarterly was too long to wait. Other accounting processes are typically handled on a quarterly or semi-annual basis because this longer frequency reflects a more appropriate trade-off of efficiency and control.
Even when computers were first used to automate bookkeeping and accounting, the old accounting calendars persisted. The limitations of early business computing technology forced system designers to use [[batch processing]]. From an accounting process standpoint, batch systems don’t offer much of an improvement over paper-based ones in changing the timing of finance and accounting processes. They impose the same need to balance efficiency and control in taking computing systems off-line to handle computations and summarizations in a way that doesn’t interfere with transactions processing. Only within the past decade has information technology reached a performance threshold that eliminates the need for such batch processing. Corporations that use batch-less accounting systems have greater freedom to schedule their accounting cycle.
The third principle of continuous accounting is continuous (or continual) improvement. Decades ago, continuous improvement revolutionized manufacturing worldwide and culture of manufacturing departments. Continuous improvement can be used as a management approach to overcome organizational inertia. This is particularly difficult in accounting departments because accounting is a discipline that requires consistency, which is necessary for the faithful presentation of a company’s financial performance and health. But performing accounting processes the same way may not be the best way.
Continuous improvement requires ongoing assessments to identify issues and how to address them, as well as a mindset that accepts that these sorts of changes will be made.

'''DataOps''' is an automated, process-oriented methodology, used by analytic and data teams, to improve the quality and reduce the cycle time of [[Data analysis|data analytics]]. While DataOps began as a set of best practices, it has now matured to become a new and independent approach to data analytics.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.datasciencecentral.com/profiles/blogs/dataops-it-s-a-secret|title=DataOps – It’s a Secret|website=www.datasciencecentral.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-05}}</ref> DataOps applies to the entire data lifecycle<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/DataOps|title=What is DataOps (data operations)? - Definition from WhatIs.com|work=SearchDataManagement|access-date=2017-04-05|language=en-US}}</ref> from data preparation to reporting, and recognizes the interconnected nature of the data analytics team and information technology operations.<ref name=":0" /> From a process and methodology perspective, DataOps applies [[Agile software development]], [[DevOps]]<ref name=":0" /> and the [[statistical process control]] used in [[lean manufacturing]], to data analytics.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tamr.com/dataops-ecosystem-emerges/|title=The DataOps Ecosystem Emerges - Tamr Inc.|date=2017-05-04|work=Tamr Inc.|access-date=2017-08-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
In DataOps, development of new analytics is streamlined using [[Agile software development]], an iterative project management methodology that replaces the traditional [[Waterfall model|Waterfall sequential methodology]]. Studies show that software development projects complete significantly faster and with far fewer defects when Agile Development is used. The Agile methodology is particularly effective in environments where requirements are quickly evolving — a situation well known to data analytics professionals.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/data-ops/how-software-teams-accelerated-average-release-frequency-from-12-months-to-three-weeks-5cb86c2b551e|title=How Software Teams Accelerated Average Release Frequency from 12 Months to Three Weeks|last=DataKitchen|date=2017-02-21|website=Medium|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref>
[[DevOps]] focuses on continuous delivery by leveraging on-demand IT resources and by automating test and deployment of analytics. This merging of software ''development'' and IT ''operations'' has improved velocity, quality, predictability and scale of software engineering and deployment. Borrowing methods from DevOps, DataOps seeks to bring these same improvements to data analytics.<ref name=":0" />
Like [[lean manufacturing]], DataOps utilizes [[statistical process control]] (SPC) to monitor and control the data analytics pipeline. With SPC in place, the data flowing through an operational system is constantly monitored and verified to be working. If an anomaly occurs, the data analytics team can be notified through an automated alert.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/data-ops/lean-manufacturing-secrets-that-you-can-apply-to-data-analytics-31d1a319cbf0|title=Lean Manufacturing Secrets that You Can Apply to Data Analytics|last=DataKitchen|date=2017-03-07|website=Medium|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref>
DataOps is not tied to a particular technology, architecture, tool, language or framework. Tools that support DataOps promote collaboration, orchestration<ref name=":2" />, agility<ref name=":3" />, quality, security, access and ease of use.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nexla.com/define-dataops/|title=What is DataOps? {{!}} Nexla: Scalable Data Operations Platform for the Machine Learning Age|website=www.nexla.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref>
== History ==
DataOps was first introduced by Lenny Liebmann, Contributing Editor, InformationWeek, in a blog post on the IBM Big Data & Analytics Hub titled "3 reasons why DataOps is essential for big data success" on June 19, 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibmbigdatahub.com/blog/3-reasons-why-dataops-essential-big-data-success|title=3 reasons why DataOps is essential for big data success|work=IBM Big Data & Analytics Hub|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref> The term DataOps was later popularized by Andy Palmer at Tamr.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tamr.com/from-devops-to-dataops-by-andy-palmer/|title=From DevOps to DataOps, By Andy Palmer - Tamr Inc.|date=2015-05-07|work=Tamr Inc.|access-date=2017-03-21|language=en-US}}</ref> DataOps is a moniker for "Data Operations."<ref name=":5" /> 2017 was a significant year for DataOps with significant ecosystem development, analyst coverage, increased keyword searches, surveys, publications, and open source projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/data-ops/2017-the-year-of-dataops-b2023c17d2af|title=2017: The Year of DataOps|last=DataKitchen|date=2017-12-19|website=data-ops|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref> [[File:Dataops.gif|thumb|DataOps heritage from DevOps, Agile, and manufacturing]]
== Goals and Philosophy ==
The volume of data is forecast to grow at a rate of 32% CAGR to 180 Zettabytes by the year 2025 (Source: IDC).<ref name=":4" /> DataOps seeks to provide the tools, processes, and organizational structures to cope with this significant increase in data.<ref name=":4" /> Automation streamlines the daily demands of managing large integrated databases, freeing the data team to develop new analytics in a more efficient and effective way.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ciodive.com/news/5-trends-driving-big-data-in-2017/445239/|title=5 trends driving Big Data in 2017|work=CIO Dive|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
DataOps embraces the need to manage many sources of data, numerous data pipelines and a wide variety of transformations.<ref name=":0" /> DataOps seeks to increase velocity, reliability, and quality of data analytics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dbta.com/Editorial/News-Flashes/Unravel-Data-Advances-Application-Performance-Management-for-Big-Data-116893.aspx|title=Unravel Data Advances Application Performance Management for Big Data|date=2017-03-10|work=Database Trends and Applications|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en-US}}</ref> It emphasizes communication, collaboration, integration, automation, measurement and cooperation between [[data scientists]], analysts, data/ETL[[Extract, transform, load|(extract, transform, load]]) engineers, [[Information technology|information technology (IT)]], and quality assurance/governance.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/data-ops/how-to-become-a-rising-star-with-data-analytics-6e4f611e85dd|title=How to Become a Rising Star with Data Analytics|last=DataKitchen|date=2017-03-15|website=data-ops|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref> It aims to help organizations rapidly produce insight, turn that insight into operational tools, and continuously improve analytic operations and performance.<ref name=":6" />
== Implementation == Toph Whitmore at Blue Hill Research, offers these DataOps leadership principles for the [[information technology]] department:<ref name=":1" /> * ''“Establish progress and performance measurements at every stage of the data flow. Where possible, benchmark data-flow cycle times.'' * ''Define rules for an abstracted semantic layer. Ensure everyone is “speaking the same language” and agrees upon what the data (and metadata) is and is not.'' * ''Validate with the “eyeball test”: Include continuous-improvement -oriented human feedback loops. Consumers must be able to trust the data, and that can only come with incremental validation.'' * Automate as many stages of the data flow as possible including BI, data science, and analytics. * ''Using benchmarked performance information, identify bottlenecks and then optimize for them. This may require investment in commodity hardware, or automation of a formerly-human-delivered data-science step in the process.'' * ''Establish governance discipline, with a particular focus on two-way data control, data ownership, transparency, and comprehensive data-lineage tracking through the entire workflow.'' * ''Design process for growth and extensibility. The data flow model must be designed to accommodate volume and variety of data. Ensure enabling technologies are priced affordably to scale with that enterprise data growth.”''
== DataOps Manifesto ==
Individuals and organizations supporting DataOps have produced a [http://dataopsmanifesto.org DataOps manifesto], consisting of 18 DataOps principles, which summarize the mission, values, philosophies, goals and best practices of DataOps practitioners.
== The Role of DataOps Engineer ==
The DataOps Engineer orchestrates and automates the data analytics pipeline, promotes features to production and automates quality.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/data-ops/building-a-dataops-team-abc375e0a6bc|title=Building a DataOps Team|last=DataKitchen|date=2017-07-19|website=data-ops|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> In many organizations, the DataOps engineer is a separate role. In others, it is a shared function.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/data-ops/dataops-engineer-will-be-the-sexiest-job-in-analytics-9c38bf444e5a|title=DataOps Engineer Will Be the Sexiest Job in Analytics|last=DataKitchen|date=2017-05-16|website=Medium|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref>
== More DataOps Information == * The DataOps [https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLVbsAdgZXvtyy6HVKCP0HChjCcq2oW3eK YouTube channel] hosts videos on DataOps-related topics from various sources. * The DataOps [https://paper.li/datakitchen_io/1525109892#/ Weekly News] hosts stories on DataOps-related topics from various sources. * The DataOps [https://www.slideshare.net/datakitchen99 Slideshare Channels] hosts presentations on DataOps-related topics from various sources. * The DataOps https://medium.com/data-ops Blog] has blog posts on DataOps.

{{About|the professor from MIT|others named|Douglas Macgregor (disambiguation)}} '''Douglas Murray McGregor''' (1906 – 1 October 1964) was a [[management]] professor at the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] and president of [[Antioch College]] from 1948 to 1954.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://antiochiana.antioch.edu/PresidentsList.htm| title=Presidents of Antioch| accessdate=4 September 2011| publisher=Antioch University| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001132949/http://antiochiana.antioch.edu/PresidentsList.htm| archivedate=1 October 2011| df=}}</ref> He also taught at the [[Indian Institute of Management Calcutta]]. His 1960 book ''The Human Side of Enterprise'' had a profound influence on education practices.
Douglas McGregor is a contemporary of Abraham Maslow. Likewise, he also contributed much to the development of the management and motivational theory. He is best known for his [[Theory X and Theory Y]] as presented in his book ‘The Human Side of Enterprise’ (1960), which proposed that manager’s individual assumptions about human nature and behaviour determined how individual manages their employees.<ref name="Ibrahim, 2012">Jeong Chun Hai @Ibrahim, & Nor Fadzlina Nawi. (2012). Principles of Public Administration: Malaysian Perspectives. Kuala Lumpur: Pearson Publishers. {{ISBN|978-967-349-233-6}}</ref>
==Career== McGregor was born in [[Detroit]]. He earned a [[Bachelor of Engineering|B.E. (Mechanical)]] from Rangoon Institute of Technology, an [[B. A.]] from [[Wayne State University]] in 1932, then earned an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] and [[Ph.D.]] in psychology from [[Harvard University]] in 1933 and 1935 respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://antiochiana.antioch.edu/McGregor%20cv.htm |title=Douglas McGregor |publisher=Antioch University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023063315/http://antiochiana.antioch.edu/McGregor%20CV.htm |archivedate=October 23, 2007 }}</ref>
==''The Human Side of Enterprise''==
In the book ''The Human Side of Enterprise'', McGregor identified an approach of creating an environment within which employees are motivated via authoritative direction and control or integration and self-control, which he called [[theory X and theory Y]],<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/education/higher/specials/mit150/mitlist/?page=full|title=The MIT 150: 150 Ideas, Inventions, and Innovators that Helped Shape Our World|publisher=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=May 15, 2011|accessdate=August 8, 2011}}</ref> respectively. Theory Y is the practical application of Dr. [[Abraham Maslow]]'s Humanistic School of Psychology, or Third Force psychology, applied to scientific management.
He is commonly thought of as being a ''proponent'' of Theory Y, but, as [[Edgar Schein]] tells in his introduction to McGregor's subsequent, posthumous (1967), book ''The Professional Manager'' : "In my own contacts with Doug, I often found him to be discouraged by the degree to which theory Y had become as monolithic a set of principles as those of Theory X, the over-generalization which Doug was fighting....Yet few readers were willing to acknowledge that the content of Doug's book made such a neutral point or that Doug's own presentation of his point of view was that coldly scientific".
[[Graham Cleverley]] in ''Managers & Magic'' (Longman's, 1971) comments: "...he coined the two terms [[Theory X and theory Y]] and used them to label two sets of beliefs a manager might hold about the origins of human behaviour. He pointed out that the manager's own behaviour would be largely determined by the particular beliefs that he subscribed to....McGregor hoped that his book would lead managers to investigate the two sets of beliefs, invent others, test out the assumptions underlying them, and develop managerial strategies that made sense in terms of those tested views of reality. "But that isn't what happened. Instead McGregor was interpreted as advocating Theory Y as a new and superior ethic - a set of moral values that ''ought'' to replace the values managers usually accept."
''The Human Side of Enterprise'' was voted the fourth most influential management book of the 20th century in a poll of the Fellows of the [[Academy of Management]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Bedeian |first1= Arthur G. |last2= Wren |first2= Daniel A. |author-link1= Arthur G. Bedeian|author-link2=Daniel A. Wren| date= Winter 2001 |title= Most Influential Management Books of the 20th Century |journal= Organizational Dynamics |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages= 221–225 |doi= 10.1016/S0090-2616(01)00022-5 | url = http://www.bus.lsu.edu/bedeian/articles/MostInfluentialBooks-OD2001.pdf}}</ref>
==Legacy== McGregor died, age 58, in [[Massachusetts]]. In 1964, the School of Adult and Experiential Learning at Antioch College was renamed the "McGregor School" in his honor. It was later renamed "Antioch University McGregor" and then "[[Antioch University Midwest]]."

'''Dulcie Boling''' (born Elizabeth Dulcie Boling on 29 March 1936) is an [[Australian people|Australian]] businessperson and magazine editor.She was born in Kyrabram, Victoria in Australia.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Clarke |first1=Patricia |title=Dulcie Boling (1936 - ) |url=http://www.academia.edu/19603059/Dulcie_Boling_1936_-_ |website=A Companion to the Australian Media |publisher=Academia.edu |accessdate=19 September 2018 |language=en}}</ref> She was [[Editor#Executive editor|editor]] of [[New Idea]] magazine from 1977 to 1993.<ref name="The Daily Telegraph (Sydney) - 19 May 2013 - ABC series Paper Giants: Magazine Wars sheds new light on editors Nene King and Dulcie Boling">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/opinion/abc-series-paper-giants-magazine-wars-sheds-new-light-on-editors-nene-king-and-dulcie-boling/story-fni0cwl5-1226645946618|title=ABC series Paper Giants: Magazine Wars sheds new light on editors Nene King and Dulcie Boling |last=Sharp |first=Annette|date=May 19, 2013|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[News Limited]]|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref> Boling was a senior executive of Southdown Press, which later became [[Pacific Magazines]].<ref name="The Daily Telegraph (Sydney) - 19 May 2013 - ABC series Paper Giants: Magazine Wars sheds new light on editors Nene King and Dulcie Boling"/>She served as the chairperson and executive chairman of Southdown Press and Chief Executive Magazines of PMP Limited from 1992-1993.<ref>{{cite web |title=Terms of Service Violation |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=11519454&privcapId=140678886&previousCapId=241286069&previousTitle=SEVEN%20GROUP%20HOLDINGS%20LTD |website=www.bloomberg.com |accessdate=19 September 2018}}</ref>
Australian actor [[Rachel Griffiths]] played Boling in the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] television [[mini-series]] ''[[Paper Giants: Magazine Wars]]'', a sequel to ''[[Paper Giants: The Birth of Cleo]]''.<ref name="The Courier-Mail - 29 May 2013 - The battle of the gossip queens in Paper Giants: Magazine Wars ">{{cite news|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/television/the-battle-of-the-gossip-queens/story-fncaks2k-1226652712267|title=The battle of the gossip queens in Paper Giants: Magazine Wars |last=Devlyn|first=Darren|date=May 29, 2013|work=[[The Courier-Mail]]|publisher=[[News Limited]]|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref>

The company has since expanded into the Middle East, with a regional office in [[Dubai]]. In 2014 Ego announced the purchase of 9.5 hectares of land in Dandenong South, building of stage one will commence in October 2015. It will be home to Ego's new global headquarters and a manufacturing center.<ref>http://www.afr.com/real-estate/commercial/big-ego-deal-for-places-victoria-estate-20130918-jh3u5</ref>
The same year Ego was awarded a $250,000 grant from the Victorian Government to extend its flammable goods production capacity in a $14.6 million investment which will boost exports by a substantial $40 million and create 63 new jobs. The expansion will also double bottle filling capacity across the business.<ref>http://www.australianmanufacturing.com.au/24035/ego-boost-create-63-new-jobs-bring-additional-40-million-victorian-export</ref>
Ego was awarded the 2015 Governor of Victoria Export Health and Biotechnology Award for outstanding international success in healthcare, presented at Government House on 30 September. <ref>http://www.egopharm.com/news/ego-awarded-as-leader-in-health-and-biotechnology-exports-from-victoria-to-the-world/</ref>
Ego provides support to a wide range of charities and community organisations, and invests in dermatological education and research.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090106162119/http://www.adna.org.au/events/conference.html ADNA – Australian Dermatology Nurses Association]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vcp.monash.edu.au/alumni/2007-winter.pdf |title=Alumni community |publisher=Vcp.monash.edu.au |date=8 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831174226/http://vcp.monash.edu.au/alumni/2007-winter.pdf |archivedate=31 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eczema.org.au/corporate.html |title=Eczema Association of Australasia Inc |publisher=Eczema.org.au |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071129205757/http://www.eczema.org.au/corporate.html |archivedate=29 November 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.curefor-eczema.com/psoriasis-association-of-singapore |title=Psoriasis Association of Singapore |publisher=curefor-eczema.com |date=}}</ref>

{{nowrap|[[Georgetown University]] ([[Master of Science|MSc]])}} | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = }} '''Ehab Al Shihabi''' (born 1970) is a Jordanian-American media professional, advisor to the Director General at [[Al Jazeera Media Network]]. He was the network's former [[Executive Director]] of international operations, [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[Al Jazeera America]], and deputy managing director of Al Jazeera English.{{cite web|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|title=Al Jazeera America Promises a More Sober Look at the News|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/19/business/media/al-jazeera-america-promises-a-more-sober-look-at-the-news.html?hp&_r=0|website=NYT|publisher=NYT|accessdate=2 October 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Hayden|first1=Eryk|title=Al Jazeera America Launch Plan: Fewer Commercials, Less Celebrity News|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/al-jazeera-america-launch-plan-607325|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=2 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Al Jazeera America Taps Ehab Al Shihabi To Be Interim CEO|url=http://deadline.com/2013/07/al-jazeera-america-names-ehab-shihabi-ceo-546620/|website=Deadline|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=2 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Kate O'Brian and Ehab Al Shihabi|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-al-jazeera-kate-obrian-20130722-001-photo.html|website=LAT|publisher=LAT|accessdate=2 October 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|title=Al Jazeera America Shifts Focus to U.S. News|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2013/05/27/business/media/american-al-jazeera-channel-shifs-focus-to-us-news.html?from=us|website=NYT|publisher=NYT|accessdate=2 October 2015}} Shihabi is an [[Edward R. Murrow]] Center Senior Fellow at The [[Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]], and writes opinion pieces for ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', ''Inc. Magazine'', and other outlets. ==Early life and education== Shihabi was born in [[Amman, Jordan]] in 1970. He is both an American and Jordanian citizen. He earned his BSc in Management from the [[University of Jordan]] in 1993. He then went on to earn his MBA from the University of Jordan in 1996 before earning his MSc in Leadership and Strategy from [[Georgetown University]] in 2006.{{cite web|last1=Steel|first1=Emily|title=Ehab Al Shihabi, Al Jazeera’s quiet American|website=Financial Times|accessdate=2 October 2015}} ==Career== Ehab Al Shihabi started his career as a management consultant at [[Arthur_Andersen#Andersen_Consulting_and_Accenture|Andersen Consulting]] in 1997. He later worked for [[KPGM]] and [[Deloitte]]. Shihabi was hired by [[Al Jazeera Media Network]] in 2009 to be the Deputy Managing Director at [[Al Jazeera English]].{{cite web|last1=Koblin|first1=John|title=Al Jazeera America Chief Is Ousted After Turmoil|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/07/business/media/al-jazeera-america-chief-is-ousted-after-turmoil.html?_r=0|website=NYT|publisher=NYT|accessdate=9 October 2015}} In 2011 he was named the Executive Director of international operations Al Jazeera Media Network. He was one of the principal people involved in the process of buying [[Current TV]] for $500 million and setting up [[Al Jazeera America]] (reaching 60 million homes), as well as [[Al Jazeera Türk]] and [[Al Jazeera Balkans]]. Shihabi stated in regards to the launch of Al Jazeera America: "It's going to be run by American talent and staff for the American audience", adding there would be "less opinion, less yelling and fewer celebrity sightings".{{cite web|last1=Rackl |first1=Lori |title=Al Jazeera adding Chicago reporters in push to expand U.S. audience |url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/television/19799118-421/al-jazeera-adding-chicago-reporters-in-push-to-expand-us-audience.html |website=Chicago Sunday Times |publisher=Chicago Sunday Times |accessdate=2 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130802133217/http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/television/19799118-421/al-jazeera-adding-chicago-reporters-in-push-to-expand-us-audience.html |archivedate=August 2, 2013 }} He defined the channel as providing "accurate, in-depth, unbiased news stories". [[Bob Meyers (journalist)|Bob Meyers]], president of the [[National Press Foundation]], titled that Jazeera's launch as "transformative". Shihabi had been largely involved in the business aspects of Al Jazeera America such as the budget for the channel and helping in securing carriage agreements with television carriers and making the channel available on different platforms such as carrier TV Everywhere platforms, in other words continuing its [[brand management|branding]] and awareness campaigns, while expanding its cable distribution and online presence.{{cite web|last1=Weprin|first1=Alex|title=Al Jazeera America C.E.O. previews ‘year two’ in staff memo|url=http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/media/2014/08/8550325/al-jazeera-america-ceo-previews-year-two-staff-memo|website=Capitalnewyork|publisher=Capitalnewyork|accessdate=9 October 2015}} Since January 2013, 900 people were hired for the new venture, a great part from other networks such as CNN and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], including [[John Seigenthaler]] and [[Kate O'Brian]].{{cite web|title=Al Jazeera America announces launch date|url=https://en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com/al-jazeera-america-announces-launch-date-233606479.html|website=YahooNews|publisher=AlJazeera|accessdate=9 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Al Jazeera America Taps Ehab Al Shihabi To Be Interim CEO|url=http://deadline.com/2013/07/al-jazeera-america-names-ehab-shihabi-ceo-546620/|website=Deadline|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=9 October 2015}} During his tenure, Al Jazeera America's ratings grew for three continuous quarters, and topped at three million unique viewers in the first two weeks of July 2014.{{cite web|last1=Knox|first1=Merrill|title=Al Jazeera America CEO on Channel’s First Anniversary: ‘We Have Accomplished A Lot’|url=http://www.adweek.com/tvnewser/al-jazeera-america-ceo-on-channels-first-anniversary-we-have-accomplished-a-lot/235620|website=TVNewser|publisher=TVNewser|accessdate=8 October 2015}} The medium also became available to 60 million households under Al Shihabi, which is below the 100 million mark other cable broadcasters count with. The broadcaster amassed a number of journalism awards as well, including two [[Peabody Award]]s.{{cite web|last1=Hayes|first1=Dade|title=Al Jazeera America CEO and President Say Net is On Course|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/programming/al-jazeera-america-ceo-and-president-say-net-course/131285|website=Broadcasting & Cable|publisher=Broadcasting & Cable|accessdate=10 April He also is an [[Edward R. Murrow]] Center Senior Fellow at The [[Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]].{{cite web|last1=Al Shihabi|first1=Ehab|title=The Age of Nano News and Why We Must Pay|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ehab-al-shihabi/the-age-of-nano-news-and_b_9548224.html|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=1 April 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Al Shihabi|first1=Ehad|title=What the Movie ‘Spotlight’ Says About the Future of Journalism|url=http://goodmenproject.com/arts/what-the-movie-spotlight-says-about-the-future-of-journalism-xela/|website=The Good Men Project|publisher=The Good Men Project|accessdate=1 April 2016}} ===Controversy=== In May 2015, [[Mostefa Souag]] announced Shihabi was to be replaced by [[Al Anstey]], following revelations of a lawsuit against the network by a former employee.{{cite web|last1=Wemple|first1=Erik|title=Former Al Jazeera employee sues network, alleging anti-Semitism, anti-Americanism|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2015/04/28/former-al-jazeera-employee-sues-network-alleging-anti-semitism-anti-americanism/|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=9 October 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Kasperkevic|first1=Jana|title=Al Jazeera America CEO fired amid reports of turmoil in the newsroom|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/may/06/al-jazeera-america-ceo-fired-amid-reports-of-turmoil-in-the-newsroom|website=The Guardian|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=8 October 2015}} The broadcaster also faced a $15 million discrimination lawsuit.
