{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission |nativename = |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 1988 |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[India]] |headquarters = [[New Delhi]]{{cite web|title=NCDRC - Contact Info|url=http://ncdrc.nic.in/directory.html|publisher=NCDRC|accessdate=4 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128223647/http://ncdrc.nic.in/directory.html|archivedate=28 January 2013|df=}}|employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = Justice [[Rajesh_Kumar_Agrawal|R K AGRAWAL]] |chief1_position = President, NCDRC |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{URL|ncdrc.nic.in}} |footnotes = }} The '''National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC)''', [[India]] is a [[Quasi-judicial body|quasi-judicial]] [[Government agency|commission]] in [[India]] which was set up in 1988 under the [[Consumer Protection Act, 1986]]. Its head office is in [[New Delhi]]. The commission is headed by a sitting or retired judge of the [[Supreme Court of India]]. The present head is Justice [[Rajesh_Kumar_Agrawal|R K AGRAWAL]], former judge of the Supreme Court of India.{{cite web|title=NCDRC Website Home Page|url=http://ncdrc.nic.in/|publisher=NCDRC|accessdate=18 December 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721172525/http://ncdrc.nic.in/|archivedate=21 July 2011}} == Jurisdiction == Section 21 of Consumer Protection Act, 1986 describes, the National Consumer shall have jurisdiction:- to enter a complaint valued more than 1 crore and also have Appellate and Revisional jurisdiction from the orders of State Commissions.
  1. to entertain:
    1. complaints where the value of the goods or services and compensation, if any, claimed exceeds rupees one crore; and
    2. appeals against the orders of any State Commission; and
  2. to call for the records and pass appropriate orders in any consumer dispute which is pending before or has been decided by any State Commission where it appears to the National Commission that such State Commission has exercised a jurisdiction not vested in it by law, or has failed to exercise a jurisdiction so vested, or has acted in the exercise of its jurisdiction illegally or with material irregularity.
== Appeal == Section 23 of Consumer Protection Act, 1986, provides that any person aggrieved by an order of NCDRC, may prefer an Appeal against such order to [[Supreme Court of India]] within a period of 30 days. == See also == * [[Manu Needhi Consumer and Environmental Protection Centre]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://ncdrc.nic.in/}} {{Indian commissions}} [[Category:Indian commissions and inquiries]] [[Category:1988 establishments in India]] [[Category:Quasi-judicial bodies of India]] [[Category:Consumer organisations based in India]] [[Category:Legal organisations based in India]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1988]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2013}} [[Image:Sr Maigh Eala.jpg|225px|thumb|Georgian Streetscape on Mallow Street]] '''Newtown Pery''' is an area of central [[Limerick]], [[Ireland]], and forms the main [[city centre]] (or [[Central Business District|CBD]]) of the city. The district is known for its [[Georgian architecture|Georgian architectural]] heritage and is the core area of Limerick's Georgian Quarter. It is one of the three towns that make up modern-day Limerick City Centre, the other two being the older ''[[King's Island, Limerick|Englishtown]] & [[Irishtown, Limerick|Irishtown]]'' which date from the medieval period. Newtown Pery houses the largest collection of Georgian townhouses in Ireland outside of [[Georgian Dublin|Dublin]]. In 1837, [[Samuel Lewis (publisher)|Samuel Lewis]] in his ''Topographical Dictionary of Ireland'' described Newtown Pery as ‘one of the handsomest towns in Ireland’.<ref name="libraryireland.com">http://www.libraryireland.com/topog/L/Limerick-City-Topography.php</ref>
==History== [[File:Limerick - O'Connell Street looking north east - geograph.org.uk - 331730.jpg|225px|thumb|Limerick - O'Connell Street looking north east. The majority of this section of Newtown Pery was rebuilt in the mid to late 20th Century]] Prior to the development of Newtown Pery, the historical City of Limerick was situated just north of the present day city centre, stretching from [[King John's Castle (Limerick)|King John's Castle]] towards where [[St John's Cathedral (Limerick)|St. John's Cathedral]] is today. The city was made up of two distinct towns; [[King's Island, Limerick|Englishtown]] (populated by [[Old English (Ireland)|Old English]] settlers) located on the historical island city and [[Irishtown, Limerick|Irishtown]] (populated by natives) located on the southern bank of the Abbey River.<ref name="limerickcity.ie">http://www.limerickcity.ie/media/limerick%20history%2005.pdf</ref> The two towns were connected by one bridge ''Baal's Bridge'' over the Abbey River, while ''Thomond Bridge'' beside [[King John's Castle (Limerick)|King John's Castle]] was a major crossing point of the [[River Shannon]] from ''Englishtown'' into modern-day [[County Clare]]. As with most cities of this time, Limerick was heavily fortified and walled and the streets were characteristically narrow, winding & cramped.<ref name="libraryireland.com"/><ref name="limerickcity.ie"/> Prior to the construction of Newtown Pery, Limerick was also beginning to exhibit some early Georgian styles within the old city. Examples surviving today include; the ''Old Bishop's Palace'' at ''Castle Street'' & at ''John's Square'' (Limerick's first example of fashionable architecture and civic spaces). Early photographs of the old city areas also show the old (pre-Georgian) continental & [[Dutch gable]]d styled townhouses as being altered somewhat to appear more Georgian. Very few of these survive today. Originally the land south of the medieval city that was to become Newtown Pery was owned by the [[Franciscans]] and known as ''South Priors Land''. Following the [[dissolution of the monasteries]] by [[Henry VIII]] this land was granted to Edmund Sexton of whom [[Edmund Sexton Pery]] was a descendant and on whom much of Georgian Limerick is credited.<ref name="limerickcity.ie"/><ref>http://limerickslife.com/rediscovering-limericke-3/</ref>
Following the turbulent years of the 17th century, Limerick began to prosper in the 18th century and was completely transformed into the city it is today.<ref name="georgianquarter.com">http://georgianquarter.com/264-2/</ref> Easy access from most parts of Ireland facilitated by the [[River Shannon]] & the opening of [[canals]] enabled Limerick to become the main port city on the western side of Ireland, which in turn brought much prosperity to the city and to its merchants and landowners with trade between Britain and America.<ref name="georgianquarter.com"/>
The boundaries of the city of Limerick, where the [[municipal corporation]] had authority, were smaller than the [[county of the city]] of Limerick, where the city [[grand jury]] had parallel authority. The area within the county of the city but outside the city proper was termed the city liberties. The development of Newtown Pery can be attributed to the work of [[Edmund Sexton Pery, 1st Viscount Pery|Edmund Sexton Pery]] (created [[Viscount Pery]] in 1785) and his plan for the development of a [[new town]] on lands he owned in the south liberties of the city. In 1769, he commissioned the Irish engineer [[Christopher Colles]] to design a town plan on his estate which has since become known as ''Newtown Pery''. Colles devised an impressive plan for the Pery Estate which divided the estate into a [[grid plan]] of equal rectangular plots & length and of a distinctive architectural unity which still defines the city centre to this day.<ref name="limerickcity.ie"/> The town was built in stages as Pery sold off leases to builders and developers who built 4 and 5 story townhouses in the Georgian fashion with long wide and elegant streets in [[grid plan]] design with [[O'Connell Street, Limerick|O'Connell Street]] (originally known as George's Street) as its centre, which was mostly in accordance with Colles' plan.<ref name="garrymiley.com">http://www.garrymiley.com/2007/05/05/TheConservationOfGeorgianLimerick1.aspx</ref> The earliest houses are located along Bank Place, Rutland Street, Patrick Street which were built by the Arthur family - a prominent Limerick family during the 18th century. Some of the finest examples of [[Georgian Architecture]] can be seen at the [[The Crescent (Limerick)|Crescent]] area and [[Pery Square]].<ref name="limerickcity.ie"/> The Custom's House ([[Hunt Museum]]), designed by Italian architect [[Davis Ducart]], is also one of the city's finest examples of Georgian Architecture.
By the turn of the 19th Century, Newtown Pery was rapidly growing as most fashionable area of the city. In 1807 its leading residents secured a [[private act]] of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|UK parliament]] to establish a body of [[improvement commissioners]] as municipal authority for the [[Civil parishes in Ireland|civil parish]] of St Michael's, within which Newtown Pery was located.<ref name="michaelsparishArchives">{{cite web|url=http://www.limerick.ie/historicalresources/limerickarchives/archivecollections/digitalarchives/limerickcitycouncilandlocalgovernmentcollections/commissionersfortheimprovementofst.michaelsparish1810-1851|title=Commissioners for the Improvement of St. Michael's Parish, 1810-1851|work=Archives|publisher=Limerick City and County Council|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref> The commissioners were abolished in 1853 when the area was absorbed into Limerick city.<ref name="michaelsparishArchives" /> One brake on the town's development was that the only crossing point on the Shannon remained at Thomond Bridge in the old and now less fashionable Englishtown district.<ref name="LovettWellesley">{{cite journal|last=Lovett|first=Phil|title=The Wellesley Bridge|journal=The Old Limerick Journal|issue=9|pages=28–31|url=http://www.limerickcity.ie/media/Media,3987,en.pdf}}</ref> In 1835, a new bridge was built over the Shannon connecting the west directly with Newtown Pery.<ref name="LovettWellesley" /> It was originally called Wellesley Bridge after [[Richard Wellesley, 1st Marquess Wellesley]], the [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland]] when the act to pay for it was passed.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ó Maidín|first=Pádraig|title=The Building of the Sarsfield Bridge|journal=Old Limerick Journal|issue=6|pages=5–6|url=http://www.limerickcity.ie/media/Media,3941,en.pdf}}</ref> It cemented Newtown Pery's position as Limerick's premier urban district as connections to the area improved.<ref name="LovettWellesley" /> The five-arch bridge was designed by [[Alexander Nimmo]] based on the [[Pont de Neuilly]] in [[Paris]]. In 1882 it was replaced with the current [[Sarsfield Bridge]].<ref name="LovettWellesley" />
==Details== [[File:Limerick4.JPG|thumb|Tait Memorial Clock Tower & Dominican Church, Baker Place]] From its development Newtown Pery has served as Limerick's [[Central Business District|CBD]]. It is also the city's main retail district which is centered on [[O'Connell Street, Limerick|O'Connell Street]], [[William Street, Limerick|William Street]] and the adjoining streets. In addition to the quality of the Georgian heritage in the district, another striking feature of the development is the [[grid plan]] layout of the streets in the area running north/south and east/west in similar fashion and design as found in [[New York City]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Glasgow]], [[Bristol]] & [[Berlin]] albeit on a smaller scale.<ref name="garrymiley.com"/> This distinguishes Limerick's Georgian stock to the other major Irish Georgian development in Dublin, as Limerick's terraces are more uniform. This is due to the fact that the Pery owned all the land that was developed and it enabled a single development plan.
Limerick continued to expand following the [[Acts of Union 1800|Act of Union]] and into the early 19th Century, however, Pery's plan for the city was never fully realised. It was intended that the city would continue further southwards however a crippling economic decline in Ireland caused by the [[Great Irish Famine]] put an end to the development. The terrace at [[Pery Square]] was the last development of the great Georgian expansion of Limerick. The terrace itself was intended to be part of a Georgian square enclosing the People's Park, similar to [[Fitzwilliam Square]] or [[Mountjoy Square]] in [[Dublin]] however the plans were never realised as the development coincided with the beginning of the Famine. Another distinguishing feature of Georgian Limerick to Georgian Dublin is, Newtown Pery was a completely new ''greenfield'' development. Limerick's medieval city was left completely intact and remains to this day. Unfortunately, most of the built infrastructure of medieval Limerick did not survive past the mid 20th Century following the clearance of slum living in the city. Some examples survive and the street outlines remain in ''Nicholas Street'', ''Mary Street'', ''Broad Street'', ''John Street'' & ''Mungret Street''. Much of Georgian Dublin in contrast however was undertaken by the [[Wide Streets Commission]] which almost completely rebuilt Dublin over the older medieval city.
==Decline== [[File:George Street, Limerick (5691906290).jpg|thumb|O'Connell Street in the early 20th century featuring the imposing facade of Cannock's Department Store & its landmark clocktower. It was rebuilt in the early 1960s, losing its Georgian character]] Although housing an important collection of Georgian architecture and acting as Limerick's city centre, unfortunately Newtown Pery's position as the one time fashionable area of the city is long over. In addition to this, its Georgian heritage has been severely compromised, in particular around the retail core of ''[[O'Connell Street, Limerick|O'Connell Street]]'' & ''[[William Street, Limerick|William street]]''. Economic decline & stagnation plagued Limerick during the 20th Century which saw some townhouses converted to tenements such as at ''Arthur's Quay & Bank Place''. During this time very little investment was seen in Newtown Pery, only the exodus of families & industries to new suburban districts around the city due to modern requirements. By the mid 20th century dereliction had taken its toll as the townhouses at ''Arthur's Quay'', ''Francis Street'' & ''Bank Place'' were completely lost. Lax development controls enabled the almost complete rebuilding of the northern end of O'Connell Street and replacing what were some iconic and illustrious buildings with more [[modernist]] (& perhaps less attractive) sixties style architecture. The loss of ''Todd's Department Store'' to a fire which gutted the building, the rebuilding of ''Cannock's Department Store, Royal George Hotel, AIB Bank'' amongst many more, completely altered the look of city and ultimately resulted in a loss of the districts heritage and character. Nevertheless, much of the districts Georgian townhouses remained intact, however many were converted to offices or flats while others remained unoccupied or neglected. However, despite the architectural losses & economic conditions; Newtown Pery remained the premier retail & services district for Limerick and the greater [[Mid-West Region, Ireland|Mid-West Region]] well up into the late 20th and early 21st Century.
Economic stagnation in Limerick, was only broken by the [[Celtic Tiger]] in the late 20th Century. Unfortunately, Newtown Pery, still lagged behind with regards to investment & planning with exception to the riverfront of the [[River Shannon|Shannon]]. Suburban areas of Limerick have seen massive investments particularly in retail, which has seen the one time retail core of ''[[O'Connell Street, Limerick|O' Connell Street]] & [[William Street, Limerick|William street]]'' been eclipsed by massive retail developments in the suburbs. Poor planning & lack of investment has resulted in high vacancy rates & further dereliction which plagues some parts. Amongst the casualties of this poor planning has been the ''[[Patrick Street, Limerick|Patrick Street]], [[Rutland Street, Limerick|Rutland Street]] & Ellen Street'' areas which were all part of the ill fated [[Opera Centre]] development. These streets are now almost completely derelict & vacant. [[Urban decay|Urban depression]] in Limerick unfortunately is not confined to these areas alone as much of central Limerick is now exhibiting the effects, mainly of heavy suburbanisation but also the effects of economic recession. The area is now a shadow of its former self as more and more businesses & retail facilities leave the city centre for the convenience of the new shopping centres.
==Future== In order to arrest the decline of Limerick's CBD and Newtown Pery in general, both [[Limerick City Council]] and national government have introduced schemes to counteract the heavy suburbanisation of the city. Amongst the most eloborate plans is the €250 million ''Limerick 2030'' plan which will see a complete redevelopment of the ''Arthur's Quay'' area into a new and modern retailing complex.<ref name="ReferenceA">http://www.limerickcity.ie/Planning/EconomicDevelopment/Limerick2030AnEconomicandSpatialPlanforLimerick/</ref> It will also see the development of a higher education campus to include facilities from [[Limerick Institute of Technology|LIT]], [[University of Limerick|UL]], and [[Mary Immaculate College|MIC]] and a refurbishment of the city's main streets.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Another plan is the ''Living City Initiative'' which provides tax relief for residents who refurbish Georgian houses in designated areas. It also provides tax relief to retailers who carry out works to upgrade or re-fit their shops in the designated Georgian area.<ref>http://www.limerick.ie/business/whatsnew/2013-02-18limerickcityandcountycouncilswelcomelivingcityinitiative.html</ref> Newtown Pery is a testament to Limerick's rich & eventful past and remains one of the most important remnants of Ireland's [[Georgian Era]]. It remains to be seen if the above schemes can stop the decline of the city's historic & elegant stock of buildings.

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Short description|Irish entrepreneur and television personality}} {{Other people}} {{Confused|Pete Casey}} {{Infobox person | name = Peter Casey | image = File:Peter-casey.jpg | birth_name = Peter Joseph Casey | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|10|9|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Derry]], [[Northern Ireland]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Greencastle, County Donegal]], Ireland | nationality = [[Irish people|Irish]] | party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] | spouse = {{marriage|Helen Casey|1990}} | children = 5 | education = [[St Columb's College]] | alma_mater = [[Aston University]] | known_for = Dragon on the Irish version of ''[[Dragons' Den]]'', candidate in the [[Irish presidential election, 2018|2018 Irish presidential election]] | occupation = {{Hlist|[[Entrepreneur]]|[[Businessman]]}} | website = {{URL|petercasey.ie}} }} '''Peter Joseph Casey''' (born 9 October 1957) is an Irish entrepreneur and television personality. He is the founder and former Executive Chairman of Claddagh Resources, a global recruitment and executive search business. He is best known as an investor on the [[RTÉ]] television programme ''[[Dragons' Den (Irish TV series)|Dragons' Den]]'', in which he was one of the Dragons. He was an unsuccessful candidate in the [[Irish presidential election, 2018|2018 Irish presidential election]], coming second.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Leahy | first1=Pat | last2=McGee | first2=Harry | date=29 October 2018 | title=Higgins begins preparations for second term after landslide victory | url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/higgins-begins-preparations-for-second-term-after-landslide-victory-1.3678961 | work=The Irish Times | access-date=30 October 2018 }}</ref>
==Early and personal life== Casey was born in [[Derry]] on 9 October 1957. He is the third of nine children (five boys and four girls). His mother Patsy Casey was deputy headmistress at Nazareth House Primary School and his father Leo was the bursar at the local grammar school, [[St Columb's College]]. Casey attended both schools before studying business administration, politics and economics at [[Aston University]] in [[Birmingham]]. He lived in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], with his second wife, Helen and their five children. In 2016 Casey sold his mansion in Georgia and now lives in a house in [[Greencastle, County Donegal]].<ref name="Independent2018-10-15">{{cite news |title=Presidential candidate Peter Casey downsizes from €1.7m mansion to Donegal house with sea view |url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/presidential-election-2018/presidential-candidate-peter-casey-downsizes-from-1-7m-mansion-to-donegal-house-with-sea-view-37419360.html |accessdate=22 October 2018 |work=independent.ie |date=15 October 2018}}</ref>
==Business career== Casey joined Rank Xerox UK as a sales representative in 1979, and went on to win a national award for sales in his first year. He moved to [[Sydney]], Australia in 1981, and was ranked in the top 5% of sales executives nationally. He became the youngest district manager in [[Rank Xerox]] and won Three Oceans Cup as top Sales Manager in [[Asia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishabroad.com/IrishWorld/IrishAmericaMag/decjan07-old/features/Business100ProfilesandBostonHonorees.asp|title=Profiles|work=Irish Abroad}}</ref> In 1983, Casey joined Océ Reprographics as state manager for [[New South Wales]]. He then rejoined Rank Xerox in 1984 as a branch manager in Sydney, before making the decision to set up his first company, The Trinity Group, in 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=7715175&privcapId=7715151|title=Executive Profile|work=Bloomberg Businessweek}}</ref> The Trinity Group, a search and IT contracting firm based in Sydney, was one of five firms awarded the NSW Government tender to supply temporary staff to the New South Wales Government, the largest contract ever awarded in staffing at the time. Casey sold this business in 1992, and moved back to Ireland for six months before setting out for Atlanta, Georgia where he founded Network Resources which later became Claddagh Resources in 1996. Claddagh Resources place high-level executives across the globe for many Fortune 500 companies including Coca-Cola, SAP, Tata Consultancy Services, Oracle, IBM, and Ernst & Young. In 2000, the company established its European headquarters in [[Donegal]] which has recently expanded operations to a new [[Dublin]] office. ''Irish America Magazine'' named him as one of 2007's leading [[Irish Americans|Irish American]] businessmen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/dragonsden/profile_petercasey.html|title=Profile:Peter Casey|publisher=[[RTÉ Television]]}}</ref>
==Television== Ireland's version of the business-related TV programme ''[[Dragons' Den]]'' selected Casey to appear as an investor for the show's fifth and sixth series.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allaboutbusiness.ie/denlive/dragons/Peter_Casey |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308061837/http://www.allaboutbusiness.ie/denlive/dragons/Peter_Casey |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-03-08 |title=ALL ABOUT PETER |work=[[Bank of Ireland]] }}</ref><ref name=irishexaminer_14042013>{{cite news|first=Hillary|last=Fennel|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/features/interviews/this-much-i-know-peter-casey-227974.html|title=This much I know: Peter Casey|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=14 April 2013}}</ref> Over the course of the series he made several investments.
==Politics== In January 2015, Casey said he would consider running as a candidate at the [[Irish general election, 2016|next Irish general election]], though he expressed uncertainty about which constituency he might choose. When pressed to name a constituency he thought he might select [[Donegal (Dáil constituency)|Donegal]], where he had recently purchased a home, or somewhere in Dublin, where he intended to set up his latest business. "Realistically I'm going to be spending a lot of time in Dublin", Casey said at the time.<ref name=irishcentral_13012015>{{cite news|first=Jane|last=Walsh|url=http://www.irishcentral.com/news/politics/US-based-Irish-businessman-to-run-for-office-as-Independent-candidate.html|title=US-based Irish businessman to run for office as Independent candidate|date=13 January 2015}}</ref> Casey gave his opinion on the [[Fine Gael]]−[[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour]] coalition to ''[[The Irish Times]]''. "In fairness to the current Government I think they have performed fairly well", he said. "Some things they have done badly but overall I'd probably give them a B [grade]."<ref name=irishcentral_13012015/> He attempted to be elected to [[Seanad Éireann]] as part of the [[Industrial and Commercial Panel]] in 2016. At his Seanad campaign launch he said he intended to support foreign direct investment, indigenous business development and job creation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/so-who-is-presidential-hopeful-peter-casey-1.3612426|title=So who is presidential hopeful Peter Casey?|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en-US}}</ref> In the count, Casey received 14 votes; 113 were required to secure a seat.
===2018 presidential campaign=== {{main|Irish presidential election, 2018}} On 30 August 2018, Casey announced his intention to seek a nomination for that year's [[Irish presidential election, 2018|Irish presidential election]]. He became the third 'dragon' from the Irish version of ''[[Dragons' Den (Irish TV series)|Dragons' Den]]'' to seek a nomination after [[Gavin Duffy]] and [[Seán Gallagher]].<ref name=RTE2018-08-30a>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/politics/2018/0830/988454-presidential-election/|title=Businessman Peter Casey seeks presidential nomination|date=30 August 2018|work=RTÉ News|access-date=30 August 2018|language=en}}</ref> Casey uploaded a promotional video entitled "Platform for President of Ireland" to YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HGzEvuTowSc&feature=youtu.be|title=Peter Casey for President of Ireland 2018|first=|last=Peter Casey|date=30 August 2018|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> He secured the nominations of four local authorities; [[Kerry County Council]], [[Clare County Council]], [[Limerick City and County Council]] and [[Tipperary County Council]].<ref name="RTE2018-09-19">{{cite news |title=Peter Casey secures nomination to contest presidency |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/politics/2018/0918/994505-presidential-election/ |access-date=17 October 2018 |work=RTÉ News |date=19 September 2018}}</ref> He criticised incumbent President [[Michael D. Higgins]] for "extolling the virtues" of [[Fidel Castro]] and [[Hugo Chávez]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/higgins-kept-seat-warm-while-being-paid-vast-amounts-of-money-millionaire-presidential-hopeful-slams-bonkers-pay-37265835.html|title='Higgins kept seat warm while being paid vast amounts of money'|work=Irish Independent|access-date=30 August 2018}}</ref>
On 17 October, Casey attracted a mixture of criticism and praise when he made comments on the ''[[Irish Independent]]'''s ''Floating Voter'' podcast regarding social housing that was offered to, and refused by, [[Irish Travellers]] in [[Thurles]], [[County Tipperary]]. Casey described Irish Travellers as "basically people camping in someone else’s land" who are "not paying their fair share of taxes in society". There were calls for Casey to withdraw from the race, including from Traveller activist group [[Pavee Point]]. Other candidates condemned Casey's comments.<ref name="Journal2018-10-17">{{cite news |title='Appalling' and 'abhorrent': All five presidential rivals round on Casey over Traveller comments |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/peter-casey-travellers-4290715-Oct2018/ |access-date=17 October 2018 |work=TheJournal.ie |date=16 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/presidential-election-2018/protests-planned-as-presidential-hopeful-peter-casey-to-visit-traveller-homes-site-37433080.html |title =Protests planned as presidential hopeful Peter Casey to visit Traveller homes site|date=18 October 2018|work=Irish Independent|access-date=18 October 2018}}</ref> In the [[Dáil Éireann|Dáil]], [[Tánaiste]] [[Simon Coveney]] referred to Casey's comments as the "lowest common denominator politics" and defended the Government's decision to recognise Irish Travellers as an [[ethnic group|ethnic minority]] in 2017, in contrast to Casey’s belief that Irish Travellers share their ethnicity with the general Irish population. <ref name="Independent2018-10-18">{{cite news |title='Lowest common denominator politics' - Simon Coveney criticises Peter Casey's comments on Travelling Community |url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/presidential-election-2018/lowest-common-denominator-politics-simon-coveney-criticises-peter-caseys-comments-on-travelling-community-37434289.html |access-date=18 October 2018 |work=Irish Independent|date=18 October 2018}}</ref> Casey visited the Thurles housing development for himself on 18 October, under [[Garda Síochána|Garda]] protection, and faced demonstrations by Traveller activist groups.<ref name="RTE2018-10-18">{{cite news |title=Protests as Casey visits housing estate for Travellers after controversial remarks |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/presidential-election/2018/1018/1005086-presidential-election/ |access-date=18 October 2018 |work=RTÉ News |date=18 October 2018}}</ref> On 19 October, Casey released a statement announcing he was "taking the weekend off from the campaign to think carefully about whether to continue in the race", adding that "I do not want the people of Ireland to elect me as President of Ireland just based on one statement I made".<ref name="Independent2018-10-19">{{cite news |title=Peter Casey suspends campaign for presidency following controversial Traveller comments |url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/presidential-election-2018/peter-casey-suspends-campaign-for-presidency-following-controversial-traveller-comments-37437133.html |access-date=19 October 2018 |work=Irish Independent|date=19 October 2018}}</ref> He announced that he was staying in the presidential election.<ref name=RTE_20181021>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/1021/1005647-peter-casey-presidential-election/|title=Peter Casey to remain in the race for Áras an Uachtaráin|work=RTÉ News|date=21 October 2018}}</ref> He also said that in his opinion that Ireland is a "welfare-dependent state" which has led to a "sense of entitlement that's become unaffordable".<ref name=RTE_20181021/><ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/live-blog-presidential-debate-4301713-Oct2018/ |title =As it happened: Presidential Debate 23 October 2018|date=23 October 2018|work=Journal|accessdate=24 October 2018}}</ref>
Casey finished second to incumbent [[Michael D. Higgins]], securing 342,727 (23.3%) votes.<ref name="examiner2018-10-26">{{cite news |title=Exit polls: Michael D Higgins set for re-election; Peter Casey comfortable runner-up |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/exit-polls-michael-d-higgins-set-for-re-election-peter-casey-comfortable-runner-up-881505.html |accessdate=27 October 2018 |work=irishexaminer.com |date=26 October 2018}}</ref> A day after the election, Casey indicated that he planned to join [[Fianna Fáil]] and run for one of the seats in the Donegal constituency in the [[Next Irish general election|next general election]]. Fianna Fáil TD [[Niall Collins]] later stated on ''[[The Week in Politics]]'' that the Fianna Fáil ticket for the constituency was full, saying that Casey should "realise that you can’t just rock up to political parties and think that you can get your way".<ref name="Journal2018-10-28">{{cite news |title='We're okay thanks': Fianna Fáil TDs pour cold water on Casey's plan to join party |url=https://www.thejournal.ie/peter-casey-fianna-fail-4310452-Oct2018/ |accessdate=28 October 2018 |work=TheJournal.ie |date=28 October 2018}}</ref> Casey responded by saying "I'm 100% serious. If the consensus after talking to them is they don’t want me, I’ll form a new party and I’ll call it the new Fianna Fáil."<ref name="independent2018-10-29">{{cite news |title='I’m 100pc serious - if they don’t want me, I’ll start the new Fianna Fáil' - Peter Casey |url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/presidential-election/im-100pc-serious-if-they-dont-want-me-ill-start-the-new-fianna-fil-peter-casey-37469995.html |accessdate=29 October 2018 |work=Irish Independent |date=29 October 2018}}</ref>
==Publications== Casey wrote a book about the history of the [[Tata Group]]. ''The World's Greatest Company'', as he called it, was published in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.derryjournal.com/news/business/magee-expansion-is-crucial-to-the-growth-of-derry-peter-casey-1-5958340|title='Magee expansion is crucial to the growth of Derry' – Peter Casey|work=[[Derry Journal]]|date=25 March 2014}}</ref>
He has also published articles in newspapers and other news publications. Writing for the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' newspaper, Casey requested voting rights for Irish emigrants.<ref>{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Casey|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/peter-casey-without-a-vote-we-emigrants-have-no-voice-in-decisions-that-affect-our-return-29618447.html|title=Peter Casey: Without a vote, we emigrants have no voice in decisions that affect our return|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|date=29 September 2013}}</ref> He argued in the ''[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]'' that Ireland has the chance to be at the centre of an online education revolution by embracing [[massive open online course]]s (MOOCs).<ref>{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Casey|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/ireland-can-play-major-role-in-online-education-revolution-30137712.html|title=Ireland can play major role in online education revolution|work=[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]|date=30 March 2014}}</ref> Writing on ''[[TheJournal.ie]]'', Casey sounded a cautionary note on [[Bitcoin]] after the collapse of virtual currency exchange Mt. Gox.<ref>{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Casey|url=http://businessetc.thejournal.ie/readme/the-two-sides-of-bitcoin-%25E2%2580%2593-is-this-virtual-currency-a-boon-or-a-threat-1368083-Mar2014/|title=Column: The two sides of bitcoin – is this virtual currency a boon or a threat?|website=[[TheJournal.ie|Business ETC]]|date=18 March 2014}}</ref> Writing in the ''Sunday Independent'', he told how credit ratings agencies made Ireland's financial crisis "explode" and suggested how it might be stopped from happening again.<ref>{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Casey|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/world/eu-could-give-us-ratings-agencies-run-for-their-money-30282121.html|title=EU could give US ratings agencies run for their money|work=[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]|date=18 May 2014}}</ref>

The '''San Leandro Tech Campus''' is a [[business park]] being constructed in downtown [[San Leandro, California]], near the [[San Leandro (BART station)|San Leandro BART station]]. Construction of Phase 1 of the project began in 2014, and was completed in 2016. The primary tenant of the first phase of construction is [[OSIsoft]], a software company based in San Leandro.<ref>[http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/johnson/article/Boom-times-come-to-downtown-San-Leandro-6840782.php]</ref> Phase 2 of the project is expected to be completed in 2019 with [[Ghirardelli Chocolate Company]] as the lead tenant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bisnow.com/san-francisco/news/office/ghirardelli-chocolate-signs-lease-at-san-leandro-tech-campus-90882|title=Ghirardelli Chocolate Signs Lease At San Leandro Tech Campus|last=|first=|date=July 23, 2018|website=Bisnow|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 10, 2018}}</ref>
The site is the permanent location for the sculpture, ''[[Truth is Beauty]]'', by [[Marco Cochrane]]. The sculpture generated some controversy, as it is a large 55' nude outdoor sculpture, albeit on private property.<ref>[https://www.sanleandro.org/depts/cd/projects/downtown_technology_campus.asp]</ref><ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/San-Leandro-Truth-is-Beauty-sculpture-nude-9145455.php]</ref><ref>[http://abc7news.com/technology/naked-sculpture-in-san-leandro-stirs-mixed-emotions/868145/]</ref><ref>[http://kron4.com/2016/10/01/truth-is-beauty-sculpture-revealed-in-san-leandro/]</ref>

Owner of [[FC Krasnodar]] | residence = [[Krasnodar]], Russia | spouse = Viktoria Galitskaya | children = Polina Galitskaya | networth = US$3.4 billion (September 2018){{cite web|title=Forbes profile: Sergei Galitsky|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/sergei-galitsky/|website=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=15 March 2018}} }} '''Sergey Nikolayevich Galitsky''' ({{lang-ru|Серге́й Николаевич Галицкий}}; born '''Sergey Nikolayevich Arutyunyan'''){{cite news|title=К нам едет ФК «Краснодар»|url=http://www.yarsport.ru/football/5350-k-nam-edet-fk-krasnodar.html|website=Yarsport.ru|accessdate=2016-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tert.am/ru/news/2013/12/12/galitski/948066 |title=Я горжусь своими армянскими корнями - Сергей Галицкий - Новости Армении - Терт.am |website=Tert.am |date= |accessdate=2016-03-09}} is a Russian [[billionaire]] businessman, the founder and co-owner of [[Magnit]], Russia's largest retailer, and president of [[FC Krasnodar]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/article/253768/galickij_v_elite |title=Галицкий в элите|website=Vedomosti.ru |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2016-03-09}} ==Early life== Sergey Arutyunyan was born on 14 August 1967, in [[Lazarevskoye Microdistrict|Lazarevskoye]], a suburb of [[Sochi]], southern Russia, his mother is Russian and his father is Armenian. He later adopted his wife's surname.{{cite web|author=Ilya Khrennikov |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-11-20/no-ally-of-putin-retail-billionaire-pinched-by-sanctions |title=No Ally of Putin, Retail Billionaire Pinched by Sanctions - Bloomberg Business |website=Bloomberg.com |date=2014-11-20 |accessdate=2016-03-09}} ==Career== In 1993, he graduated from the Economics faculty of [[Kuban State University]]. A year later, he founded the company, "Tander", which traded wholesale cosmetics and perfumery. In 1998, he built the first distribution center, and immediately after the [[1998 Russian financial crisis]], opened the first grocery store "Magnit" in [[Krasnodar]]. In 2000, he switched to retail, and created the largest network by number of stores in Russia. In 2006, the company conducted its IPO and was valued at $1.9 billion. ==Personal life== He is married to Viktoria Galitskaya, and they have one daughter, Polina Galitskaya.{{cite web|author=Maria Karnaukh |url=http://rbth.com/society/2013/06/20/seo_magazine_names_russias_88_richest_heirs_27303.html |title=СЕО magazine names Russia's 88 richest heirs | Russia Beyond The Headlines |website=Rbth.com |date=2013-06-20 |accessdate=2016-03-09}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://sputniknews.com/business/20130530/181422923/Mikhelsons-Daughter-Russias-Richest-Heiress--CEO-Magazine.html |title=Mikhelson’s Daughter Russia’s Richest Heiress – CEO Magazine |website=Sputniknews.com |date=2013-05-30 |accessdate=2016-03-09}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Sergey Galitsky}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Galitsky, Sergey}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:Russian billionaires]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian people of Armenian descent]] [[Category:People from Krasnodar]] [[Category:Russian football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:FC Krasnodar]]

[[Bharti Airtel|Airtel Kenya]] }} '''Titus Naikuni''' is a [[mechanical engineer]], [[businessman]] and corporate executive in [[Kenya]]. He is the chairman of the board of [[airtel Africa|Airtel Kenya]] and [[Rift Valley Railways Consortium]].{{cite web | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]]|location=Nairobi | url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Naikuni-to-chair-RVR-board/-/539550/2415088/-/27w1lhz/-/index.html | date=11 August 2014| title=Naikuni To Chair Rift Valley Railways Board | author=Nation Reporter |accessdate=7 November 2016}}{{cite web| url=https://citizentv.co.ke/news/former-kq-boss-titus-naikuni-qualifications-queried-97813/ | title=Former KQ boss Titus Naikuni qualifications queried |author=Benjamin Wafula |date=13 August 2015 | accessdate=7 November 2016 | publisher=Citizen TV Kenya (CTVK) | work=CTVK | location=Nairobi}} Previously, from February 2003 until December 2014, Naikuni served as the group managing director and chief executive officer of [[Kenya Airways]], the national airline carrier.{{cite web|accessdate=7 November 2016| url=http://www.nation.co.ke/business/corporates/Titus-Naikuni-Kenya-Airways-CEO-Replacement/1954162-2233876-12vv60tz/index.html | title=Kenya Airways starts search for Titus Naikuni’s replacement | date=6 March 2014 |newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] | location=Nairobi| author=Mumo Muthoki}} ==Background and education== He was born in Kenya, circa 1961. He attended [[University of Nairobi]], graduating with a [[Mechanical Engineering|Bachelor of Science in mechanical engineering]]. Later, he attended the [[Harvard Business School]]’s Management Development Programme (PMD71), in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US. He also holds an honorary doctorate in science that was awarded to him by the [[Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology]], in recognition of his contribution to development.{{cite web| accessdate=7 November 2016| url=http://nairobinews.nation.co.ke/money-spinner/naikuni-the-man-who-flew-kq-to-new-heights/ | title=Naikuni: The Man Who Flew KQ To New Heights | date=15 December 2013 | author=John Njiru |location=Nairobi | publisher=[[Daily Nation|Nairobi News]]}} ==Career== He joined the [[Magadi Soda Company]] in 1979 as a trainee engineer and rose to the positions of managing director of that company in 1995 and managing director of the Magadi Railway Company (a subsidiary of Magadi Soda Company) in 1996. Between August 1999 and March 2001, Naikuni was a member of a team of Kenyan technocrats, sponsored by the [[World Bank]], who was known as the "Dream Team". These technocrats were engaged by the government to turn around the economy. In this capacity, Naikuni served as permanent secretary in the Ministry of Transport and Communications and was a member of the board of Kenya Airways. He returned to Magadi Soda Company in April 2001, where he continued to serve as managing director, until his appointment to Kenya Airways in February 2003. Naikuni has extensive boardroom experience, having served on various company boards, including as a member of the board of [[Brunner Mond]] (South Africa), as chairman of [[Kenya Power and Lighting Company]] and as chairman of Housing Finance Company Limited. He received the Manager of the Year Award in Kenya in 2002. ==Other responsibilities== As of February 2016, Naikuni served on the boards of eight companies, including the following:{{cite web| date=18 February 2016| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Naikuni-s-Prudential-appointment-raises-board-positions-to-9/539550-3081526-item-0-7scgrnz/index.html | title=Naikuni’s Prudential appointment raises board positions to 8 | accessdate=7 November 2016 | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] | first=Juma | last=Victor | location=Nairobi}} * AccessKenya Limited * Airtel Kenya * [[Lafarge (company)|Lafarge International Advisory Board]] * [[Servair|Servair France]] * [[Tata Chemicals|Tata Chemicals Magadi]] * Prudential Life Assurance Kenya * Rift Valley Railways Consortium ==See also== * [[Kenya Airways]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Naikuni, Titus}} [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kenyan engineers]] [[Category:Kenya Airways]] [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox book | name = Toyota Kata | title_orig = | translator = | image = Cover Toyota Kata.jpg | caption = Front cover | author = Mike Rother | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Management]] | genre = | publisher = [[McGraw-Hill]] | release_date = August 4, 2009 | english_release_date = | media_type = Hardcover & eBook | pages = 306 | isbn = 978-0-07-163523-3 | dewey= 658.3/01 22 | congress= HD62.15 .R685 2010 | oclc= 459790467 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Toyota Kata''''' is a management book by [[Mike Rother]]. The book explains the Improvement Kata and Coaching Kata, which are a means for making the [[Continual improvement process]] as observed at the [[Toyota Production System]] teachable.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cis.tennessee.edu/consulting/Pages/KATA.aspx|title=Centre for Industrial services|publisher=University of Tennessee}}</ref>
==Overview== ''Toyota Kata'' defines ''management'' as, “the systematic pursuit of desired conditions by utilizing human capabilities in a concerted way.”<ref name="Rother2009.1">{{cite book|author=Mike Rother|title=Toyota Kata: Managing People for Improvement, Adaptiveness and Superior Results|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rFDq1DYprzYC|date=4 September 2009|publisher=McGraw Hill Professional|page=15|isbn=978-0-07-163985-9}}</ref> Rother proposes that it is not solutions themselves that provide sustained competitive advantage and long-term survival, but the degree to which an organization has mastered an effective routine for developing fitting solutions again and again, along unpredictable paths. This requires teaching the skills behind the solution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asq.org/training/toyota-kata-improving-and-coaching-your-way-to-success_TKWS.html|title=Toyota Kata course|publisher=ASQ}}</ref>
In this management approach a primary job of leaders and managers is to develop people so that desired results can be achieved. They do this by having the organization members (leaders and managers included) deliberately practice a routine, or [[kata]], that develops and channels their creative abilities. ''Kata'' are patterns that are practiced so they become second nature, and were originally movement sequences in martial arts.<ref name="Rother2009.1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://theleanthinker.com/2010/06/28/toyota-kata-the-how-of-engaged-leadership/|title=Toyota Kata Engaged leadership|publisher=The Lean Thinker Blog}}</ref>
==The Improvement Kata== The improvement kata is a routine for moving from the current situation to a new situation in a creative, directed, meaningful way. It is based on a four-part model: # In consideration of a vision or direction... # Grasp the current condition. # Define the next target condition. # Move toward that target condition iteratively, which uncovers obstacles that need to be worked on.
In contrast to approaches that attempt to predict the path and focus on implementation, the improvement kata builds on discovery that occurs along the way. Teams using the improvement kata learn as they strive to reach a target condition, and adapt based on what they are learning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.systems2win.com/LK/lean/kata.htm|title=Kata Habits|publisher=Systems2win}}</ref>
''Toyota Kata'' submits that the improvement-kata pattern of thinking and behavior is universal; applicable not only in business but in education, politics, daily living, etc.. The book's underlying message is that when people practice and learn a kata for how to proceed through unclear territory, they don't need to fear the obstacles, changes and unknowns they encounter. Rather than trying to hold on to a sense of certainty based on one's perspective, people can derive confidence from a kata for working through uncertainty.<ref name="Rother2009.2">{{cite book|author=Mike Rother|title=Toyota Kata: Managing People for Improvement, Adaptiveness and Superior Results|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rFDq1DYprzYC|date=4 September 2009|page=18|publisher=McGraw Hill Professional|isbn=978-0-07-163985-9}}</ref>
==The Coaching Kata== The coaching kata is a routine used to teach the improvement kata and requires prior experience with practicing the improvement kata.<ref name="Rother2009.3">{{cite book|author=Mike Rother|title=Toyota Kata: Managing People for Improvement, Adaptiveness and Superior Results|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rFDq1DYprzYC|date=4 September 2009|publisher=McGraw Hill Professional|page=171|isbn=978-0-07-163985-9}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''United States Green Chamber of Commerce''' (USGCC) is a national networking organization for businesses and community organizations that emphasize green and sustainable business practices. It asserts that sustainable business practices "spur innovation, job creation, energy efficiency and an overall brighter economic future through the triple bottom line: economic, environmental, and social sustainability." <ref>U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce [http://www.usgreenchamber.com/mission/]</ref>
==About== The USGCC was launched in 2011 as a nationwide expansion of the Green Chamber of San Diego County, co-founded by David Steel and Peter Zahn in 2009.<ref>Ariel Schwartz, “U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce Wants to Be a Networking Platform for Sustainable Businesses”, Feb 18 2011, [http://www.fastcompany.com/1729266/the-us-green-chamber-of-commerce-wants-to-be-a-networking-platform-for-sustainable-businesse], Fast Company, Retrieved: April 21, 2011</ref>
The USGCC has created strategic alliances with like-minded groups such as E2 (Environmental Entrepreneurs, Entrepreneurs' Organization), chambers and workforce partnerships to further its purpose of advancing best practices related to corporate sustainability and social responsibility.<ref>Bart King, “U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce Launches from San Diego”, February 23, 2011, [http://www.sustainablelifemedia.com/content/story/strategy/us_green_chamber_launches_from_san_diego], Sustainable Life Media, Retrieved: April 21, 2011</ref>
Prominent members include [[Toyota]], Kimpton Hotels, Northwestern Mutual, and Union Bank.<ref>Ariel Schwartz, “U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce Wants to Be a Networking Platform for Sustainable Businesses”, Feb 18 2011, [http://www.fastcompany.com/1729266/the-us-green-chamber-of-commerce-wants-to-be-a-networking-platform-for-sustainable-businesse], Fast Company, Retrieved: April 21, 2011</ref>
==2015 and beyond==
CEO Michelle Thatcher and Board of Directors chair Jim Bunch presently lead the US Green Chamber of Commerce, which has expanded into several US states including Maryland, Missouri, Florida, Iowa, Massachusetts, and New York.
Bunch is a business and life coach who has worked with Xerox, Pitney Bowes, Frito Lay, Century 21, ReMax, and Prudential.<ref>U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce[http://www.usgreenchamber.com/about/board-of-directors/]</ref> Thatcher formerly served as executive director of the Association of Florida Conservation Districts. She also serves on the advisory board of the International Green Energy Council and the World Brand Congress.<ref>U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce[http://www.usgreenchamber.com/about/staff/]</ref>

'''Vicente Soriano Serra''' (born 1953 in [[Puçol]], [[Valencian Community]], [[Spain]]) is a Valencian businessman who became the president and majority shareholder of [[Valencia CF]] in 2008, after reaching an agreement with [[Juan Bautista Soler]] to take over the presidency of the club and purchase Soler's shares to the value of 70.7 million euros. After an ill-fated attempt to resolve the club's debts, he was finally succeeded by [[Manuel Llorente]].
==Biography== Having started out in the orange export business, in the 1990s he got involved in construction as a real estate broker, and subsequently as a property developer and representative of large investor groups.
He entered the world of soccer in 2004 when forming part of [[Francisco Roig Alfonso|Paco Roig]]'s "Cor i Força", the team that was running against then ousted president [[Jaume Ortí]]. [[Juan Bautista Soler]] won the election and Soriano accepted the role offered of vice-president.<ref>[http://www.noticias.info/Archivo/2004/200410/20041006/20041006_35232.shtm Juan Bautista Soler, nuevo presidente del Valencia CF] (Juan Bautista Soler, new president of Valencia CF {{es icon}}), Valencia CF official website, October 6, 2004, (reposted on noticias.info, accessdate June 08, 2009)</ref>
Soriano was charged with the selection of plans for the new stadium (see [[Nou Mestalla]]). Finally Soler rejected said projects. As a result, his relations with the then-president deteriorated. He was relieved of the vice-presidency in January 2006, although never he sold his allocation of shares. He resigned from the board in June 2007. He threatened to return to the club accompanied by [[Juan Villalonga]] to get a hold of Soler's stock, a situation that did not bear fruit. Villalonga briefly took over the running of the club in 2008, but when he proposed to buy the 37% held by Soler, Soriano reconciled with the majority shareholder and reached an agreement for the buying and selling of the Soler family shares in an amount set at 70.7 million euros, which was overturned after Soriano failed to sell the old Mestalla ground by the end of the year, finally resigning on 4 June 2009 because he had still failed to sell it. An attempt to raise capital by improving income from television rights also failed.<ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2008/12/31/valencia/1230710021.html Las 'teles', el otro plan de Soriano] (Tellies, Soriano's other plan {{es icon}}), El Mundo, December 31, 2008 (accessdate June 08, 2009)</ref>
However, following an absence of just one month, during which time [[Manuel Llorente]] took over, Soriano returned in July, having gained 51% of the shares and linked up with a mysterious company called [[Inversiones Dalport]], an investment company supposedly from [[Uruguay]] but with an office in [[Madrid]]. Soriano announced that none of the star players such as [[David Villa]], [[Juan Manuel Mata]] or [[David Silva]] would now need to be sold, as all the debts would be wiped clean.<ref>[http://www.thetimes.co.za/Sport/Article.aspx?id=1030046 Valencia refuse to sell players], The Times, June 07, 2009 (accessdate June 08, 2009)</ref>
However, failure to find any information on Dalport on the Internet prior to the announcement prompted an outcry at the press conference. The media's suspicions were further heightened when fans noticed that the [[logo]] of an [[eagle]] used by Dalport had in fact been copied from a children's colouring-in book.<ref>[http://www.lavanguardia.es/deportes/noticias/20090706/53739362453/el-misterio-de-inversiones-dalport.html El misterio de Inversiones Dalport] (The mystery of Inversiones Dalport {{es icon}}), La Vanguardia, July 06, 2009 (accessdate July 09, 2009)</ref> Prematurely ousted president Llorente echoed the fans' suspicions <ref>[http://www.marca.com/2009/07/08/futbol/equipos/valencia/1247054723.html Llorente: "Si Soriano trae garantías bancarias, le hacemos 'pasillo'"] (If Soriano brings bank statements [ as proof ], we will hold our arms up into a tunnel for him to pass underneath {{es icon}}), Marca, July 08, 2009 (accessdate July 08, 2009)</ref> Like 70% of fans, Llorente does not believe that Soriano will deliver, and warned that Valencia is opening themselves up to a potential investment scam.<ref>[http://valenciacf.lasprovincias.es/noticias/2009-07-08/internautas-cree-soriano-20090708.html El 70% de los internautas no cree a Soriano] (70% of web users does not believe in Soriano {{es icon}}), Las Provincias, July 8, 2009 (accessdate July 8, 2009)</ref>
When, as predicted, Dalport failed to deliver, on August 21, 2009 [[Fundació VCF]] took over, becoming the main shareholder with 72.5% of shares, using a loan from [[Bancaixa]] and guaranteed by the local government. The Fundació is not allowed to end up with less than 51%, thereby ensuring stability within Valencia CF and cementing [[Manuel Llorente]] as the bona fide president.<ref>[http://www.superdeporte.es/valencia/2009/08/24/fundacio-nueva-duena-vcf/69979.html La Fundació es la nueva dueña del VCF] (The Fundació are the new owners of VCF {{es icon}}), Superdeporte, August 22, 2009 (accessdate August 26, 2009)</ref>
In 2014, Soler hired a [[hitman]] from Eastern Europe to [[kidnap]] Soriano. However, the hitman turned out to be working for the police, so Soler was arrested. While he is waiting to find out whether he will go to prison, he is not allowed to leave the country or go within 15 metres of Vicente Soriano.<ref>[http://prosoccertalk.nbcsports.com/2014/04/09/former-valencia-president-arrested-for-plotting-to-kidnap-successor/ Former Valencia president arrested for plotting to kidnap successor], NBC Sports, April 9, 2014 (accessdate April 10, 2014)</ref> This will not be easy, as his home is 20 metres from the door of Soriano's office.<ref>[http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2014/04/09/primera/1397041817_098671.html Juan Soler, imputado por tentativa de secuestro] (Juan Soler, charged with attempting kidnapping {{es icon}}), AS, April 9, 2014 (accessdate April 10, 2014)</ref>

[[New Zealand Reform Party|Reform]] (1920–25) |religion = }} '''John Vigor Brown''' (18 June 1854 – 2 September 1942), known as '''Vigor Brown''',{{cite web|title=History |url=http://www.napier.govt.nz/index.php?pid=841 |publisher=Napier City Council |accessdate=1 November 2010}} was a New Zealand [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Napier (New Zealand electorate)|Napier]], in the [[North Island]]. He was [[Mayor of Napier, New Zealand|Mayor of Napier]] for a total of 18 years. He was a well-known figure in his adopted city, a successful businessman, and involved in many clubs and organisations. ==Early life== Brown was born in [[London]] in 1854. For his parents, Jessie Gilmour and John Brown, it was their third boy and last child.{{cite news|title=Marriage |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=HBH18801203.2.8 |accessdate=10 December 2010 |newspaper=Hawke's Bay Herald |volume=XXI |issue=5845 |date=3 December 1880 |page=2}} Both parents had Scottish ancestry. His father worked for a bank, and was later a commercial traveller. The family briefly lived in France before emigrating to [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]]. John Vigor Brown, his brothers and their mother arrived in [[Melbourne]] on 22 January 1862 on the ''Water Nymph''. It is assumed that his father was already there. They made their home in [[South Yarra, Victoria|South Yarra]]. He was educated at [[Melbourne Grammar School|Melbourne Church of England Grammar School]].{{cite web | url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/biographies/3b53/1 | title= Brown, John Vigor - Biography | last= Axford | first= C. Joy | date= 1 September 2010 |publisher= [[Dictionary of New Zealand Biography]] | accessdate= 8 December 2010}} [[James Drysdale Brown]] was an elder brother.{{cite web | last = Parliament of Victoria | first = | authorlink = Parliament of Victoria | coauthors = | title = Brown, James Drysdale | work = re-member: a database of all Victorian MPs since 1851 | publisher = Parliament of Victoria | date = 2001 | url = http://www.parliament.vic.gov.au/re-member/bioregfull.cfm?mid=929 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 10 March 2016}} ==Professional career== Brown learned the trade of a wholesale merchant (clothing) at the firm Sargood, King and Sargood in Melbourne. He came to [[Wellington]] in 1875.{{sfn|Hamer|1988|p=361}} For two years, he worked for the Wellington firm of A. P. Stewart and Company as a travelling sales person.{{cite news|title=Obituary|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19420903.2.20 |accessdate=10 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=CXXXIV |issue=56 |date=3 September 1942 |page=II}} His next employment brought him to Napier, where he remained for the rest of his life. He became branch manager for [[Archibald Clark (politician)|Archibald Clark and Sons]], an importing company. He resigned from that position in May 1898{{cite book|title=The Cyclopedia of New Zealand [Taranaki, Hawke’s Bay & Wellington Provincial Districts |year=1908 |publisher=Cyclopedia Company Limited |url=http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc06Cycl-t1-body1-d2-d8-d2.html|author=Cyclopedia Company Limited |accessdate=10 December 2010 |page=316|chapter=Mr. J. Vigor Brown}} and took on the management of Neal and Close, where he was managing director at a later point. He formed his own company, J. Vigor Brown and Co. He was further managing director of White Swan Brewery, and Hawke's Bay Soap and Tannery. He was a director of the Napier Gas Company. He was the local agent for the United and Phoenix Fire Insurance Companies. ==Local body politics== He was voted onto both the Napier Harbour Board and the Napier Borough Council in 1898. He was chairman of the Harbour Board from February 1904 until April 1911.{{cite news|title=Ladies, Gentlemen and Others |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NZTR19111118.2.20 |accessdate=11 December 2010 |newspaper=NZ Truth |date=18 November 1911|issue=334 |page=4}} He was a member of the Chamber of Commerce. He was elected [[Mayor of Napier, New Zealand|Mayor of Napier]] in April 1907. He was mayor for three periods: 1907–1917, 1919–1921 and 1927–1933.{{cite web |title=Previous Mayors |url=http://www.napier.govt.nz/index.php?pid=188 |publisher=City of Napier |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522081408/http://www.napier.govt.nz/index.php?pid=188 |archive-date=22 May 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The [[1931 Hawke's Bay earthquake]] fell into Brown's last period, and temporary governance arrangement included a Napier Citizens' Control Committee, followed by a two-man Government Commission. J. S. Barton and L. B. Campbell were farewelled by the mayor in May 1933, when their term ended and the municipal affairs once again rested with the borough council.{{cite web |title=History of Napier City Council |url=http://www.napier.govt.nz/index.php?pid=605 |publisher=Napier City Council |accessdate=1 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522120209/http://www.napier.govt.nz/index.php?pid=605 |archive-date=22 May 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|title=Napier Commissioners |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19330513.2.82 |accessdate=8 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=CXV |issue=111 |date=13 May 1933 |page=12}} The resulting mayoral election was contested by the incumbent and C O Morse, the chairman of the Earthquake Relief Committee.{{cite news|title=Contests at Napier |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19330421.2.100 |accessdate=8 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=CXV |issue=93 |date=21 April 1933 |page=8}} The election caused great interest, and Morse and Brown received 4110 and 1808 votes, respectively. At the time, mayoral elections were held every two years, but the 1931 election had been skipped due to the earthquake.{{cite news|title=Results Elsewhere |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19330504.2.97.16|accessdate=8 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=CXV |issue=103 |date=4 May 1933 |page=13}}{{cite news|title=Many new members chosen|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19330504.2.97.1 |accessdate=8 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=CXV |issue=103 |date=4 May 1933 |page=13}} While mayor Brown was involved in the new [[Hawke's Bay Rugby League]] and helped them secure access to [[McLean Park]] in 1911.[http://stats.allblacks.com/asp/profile.asp?ABID=262 David Evans] ''stats.allblacks.com'' == Member of Parliament == {{NZ parlbox header|nolist=yes|align=left}} {{NZ parlbox |start = [[New Zealand general election, 1908|1908]] |end = 1911 |electorate = [[Napier (New Zealand electorate)|Napier]] |term = 17th |party = New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{NZ parlbox |start = [[New Zealand general election, 1911|1911]] |end = 1914 |electorate = Napier |term = 18th |party = New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{NZ parlbox |start = [[New Zealand general election, 1914|1914]] |end = 1919 |electorate = Napier |term = 19th |party = New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{NZ parlbox |start = {{NZ election link year|1919}} |end = 1920 |electorate = Napier |term = 20th |party = New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{NZ parlbox allegiance |start = 1920 |end = 1922 |party = New Zealand Reform Party }} {{NZ parlbox footer}} [[File:Members of the Liberal Party of the 17th parliament.jpg|thumb|300px|1910 calendar showing [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal Party]] MPs; Brown is in the left column second from the top]] The [[Napier (New Zealand electorate)|Napier]] electorate had been held since the [[New Zealand general election, 1899|1899 election]] by [[Alfred Fraser]]. Fraser stood again in the [[New Zealand general election, 1908|1908 election]], but although he was with the [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal Party]], Brown also contested the electorate as a Liberal.{{cite news|title=Hawkes Bay|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19081102.2.6.2 |accessdate=10 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=LXXVI |issue=107 |date=2 November 1908 |page=2}} Brown won the contest with a majority of 1035 votes (3803 votes to 2768).{{cite news|title=Napier Seat |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19081123.2.65 |accessdate=10 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=LXXVI |issue=123 |date=23 November 1908 |page=7}} In the [[New Zealand general election, 1911|1911 election]], Brown was challenged by [[Henry Hill (educationalist)|Henry Hill]]. Both men were supporters of the current Liberal government. Brown and Hill received 3858 and 2825 votes, respectively.{{cite news|title=Hawke's Bay Province |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=OSWCC19111212.2.58.13 |accessdate=11 December 2010 |newspaper=Otautau Standard and Wallace County Chronicle |volume=VII |issue=344 |date=12 December 1911 |page=1}}{{cite news|title=Election Campaign |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19111121.2.22 |accessdate=11 December 2010 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |volume=LXXXII |issue=123 |date=21 November 1911 |page=3}} Brown successfully contested the {{NZ election link|1919}} for the Liberal Party,{{cite news|title=The Napier Seat|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=WDT19191122.2.31.3|accessdate=18 December 2014|work=[[Wairarapa Daily Times]]|volume=45|issue=13985|date=22 November 1919|page=5}} but the party's leader, [[Joseph Ward]], failed to win re-election in the {{NZ electorate link|Awarua}} electorate. When [[Thomas Wilford]] became leader later in 1920, Brown objected{{cite news|title=Leader of the Liberals|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NZH19201008.2.92|accessdate=18 December 2014|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|volume=LVII|issue=17596|date=8 October 1920|page=6}} and transferred his allegiance to the [[New Zealand Reform Party|Reform Party]].{{cite news|title=General Elections|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NZH19221017.2.32|accessdate=18 December 2014|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|volume=LIX|issue=18223|date=17 October 1922|page=6}} Brown served in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives]] for fourteen years from 1908 to 1922.{{cite book |last= Wilson |first= James Oakley |title= New Zealand Parliamentary Record, 1840–1984 |edition= 4th |origyear= First ed. published 1913 |year= 1985 |publisher= V.R. Ward, Govt. Printer |location= Wellington |oclc=154283103 |page=186}} He contested the {{NZ election link|1922}} as the official candidate for the Reform Party and of the four candidates, he came last.{{cite book |first1=J. |last1=Hislop |title=The General Election, 1922 |year=1923 |publisher=Government Printer |url= http://atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&d=AJHR1923-I-II.2.2.5.36 |page=2 |accessdate=6 December 2014}} The reasons for this were due to a split in the Reform vote. Prime Minister [[William Massey]] had given Brown the official party endorsement, despite the local Reform committee having already chosen [[John Mason (New Zealand politician)|John Mason]] as their candidate. Neither was victorious and the seat was won by [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour's]] [[Lewis McIlvride]].{{sfn|Campbell|1975|p=110}} In {{NZ election link year|1925}}, Brown failed to receive Reform nomination with new party organizer [[Albert Davy]] ensuring it went to Mason.{{cite journal | last= Gardner | first= W.J. | date= September 1961 | title= W.F. Massey in Power | journal= Political Science | volume= 13 | issue= 2 | page= 25}} He later stood unsuccessfully as an independent in {{NZ election link year|1931}}. ==Family== Brown married Caroline Balaclava Cook, daughter of the late John Cook of [[Auckland]], on 27 November 1880 at St John's Church in Napier. They had four daughters and two sons before Caroline died from [[peritonitis]] on 6 September 1891 at the young age of 36. He remarried on 19 September 1894 to Violet McConechie Bogle. There were no further children from this second marriage. In 1910, Brown had a 31' launch built for the family, named ''Water Nymph'' after the ship used for his emigration to Victoria during his childhood.{{cite web|title=Parade of Classic & Wooden Boats Lake Rotoiti North Island, New Zealand|url=http://www.woodenboatparade.co.nz/pre1920.htm |publisher=Lake Rotoiti Classic and Wooden Boat Association|accessdate=10 December 2010}} His second wife predeceased him on 23 February 1924. Brown died on 2 September 1942 in Napier, where he had lived since 1877. [[Lincoln University (New Zealand)|Lincoln University]] }} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2010}} '''Sir Wilson James Whineray''', {{post-nominals|country=NZL|size=100%|sep=,|KNZM|OBE}} (10 July 1935 – 22 October 2012)McBride, Kerry. [https://archive.is/20130223050637/http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/rugby/all-blacks/7847665/Knighted-rugby-great-dies "Knighted Rugby Great dies"], ''[[Stuff.co.nz]]'', New Zealand, 22 October 2012. Retrieved on 22 October 2012. was a business executive and the longest-serving captain of the [[All Blacks]] until eclipsed by [[Richie McCaw]] in 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.alumni.auckland.ac.nz/uoa/af-wilson-whineray |title=Wilson Whineray – BCom |publisher=The University of Auckland |accessdate=2011-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720025743/http://www.alumni.auckland.ac.nz/uoa/af-wilson-whineray |archivedate=20 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[New Zealand|New Zealand's]] national [[rugby union]] team. Rugby writer [[Terry McLean]] considered him the All Blacks' greatest captain.{{cite web |url=http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/culture/regional-rugby/auckland |title=Auckland rugby |date=24 September 2010 |work=NZHistory.net.nz |publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage |accessdate=6 March 2011}} ==Domestic career== Owing to his early career as an agricultural cadet, which involved considerable travel around the country, Whineray played for six first-class teams, including [[Wairarapa Bush Rugby Football Union|Wairarapa]], [[Mid Canterbury Rugby Football Union|Mid Canterbury]], [[Manawatu Rugby Union|Manawatu]], [[Canterbury Rugby Football Union|Canterbury]], [[Waikato Rugby Union|Waikato]], and finally his hometown team, [[Auckland Rugby Football Union|Auckland]], for whom he made 61 appearances between 1959 and 1966. He also played for the [[North vs South rugby union match|South Island]], [[North vs South rugby union match|North Island]], and New Zealand Universities sides. ==International career== He first played for the All Blacks in 1957. The following year he became captain for the 1958 series against Australia at the young age of 23. He went on to play 77 matches for the All Blacks between 1957 and 1965, 67 of them as captain. These included 32 [[Test match (rugby union)|test match]]es, all but two of them as captain. He played mostly in the position of [[Prop (rugby union)|prop]]. Whineray was named New Zealand Sportsperson of the Year in 1965. ==Later life== After retiring from rugby, he gained a [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] from [[Harvard University]], where he was a member of the [[Harvard Business School RFC]]. He returned to New Zealand in 1969 and started work at Alex Harvey Industries, which became [[Carter Holt Harvey]].{{cite news |title=Over achiever on and off the paddock |first1=Colin |last1=Meads |first2=Andrew |last2=Stone |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/rugby/news/article.cfm?c_id=80&objectid=10677508 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=2 October 2010 |accessdate=21 August 2011}} He rose to become deputy managing director, then chairman of the board of Carter Holt Harvey, by then a major New Zealand company, and retired from the board in 2003.{{cite web |url=http://www.businesshalloffame.co.nz/whineray-wilson-james/ |title=Whineray, Wilson James |work=The Fairfax Media New Zealand Business Hall of Fame |accessdate=21 August 2011}} He was the managing director of NZ Wool Marketing Corporation in 1973–74, chairman of the [[National Bank of New Zealand]], and a director of [[Auckland Airport|Auckland International Airport]] and [[APN News & Media]]. He was chairman of the [[Hillary Commission]], a sports funding body, from 1993 to 1998.{{cite news |title=Seven All Black knights |first=Keith |last=Quinn |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/rugby-news/keith-quinn-seven-all-black-knights-4211719 |newspaper=One Sport |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=21 August 2011}} He was the honorary Colonel Commandant of the [[New Zealand Special Air Service]] from 1997 to 2001.{{cite news |title=Top three new constables go to Auckland area |url= http://www.police.govt.nz/news/release/981.html |publisher=New Zealand Police |date=12 June 2003 |accessdate=21 August 2011}}{{cite news |title=Kiwi SAS soldier died saving lives |first=Vernon |last=Small |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/sunday-star-times/news/5480236/Kiwi-SAS-soldier-died-saving-lives |newspaper=Sunday Star Times |date=21 August 2011 |accessdate=21 August 2011}} Whineray was knighted in 1998 "for services to sport and business management".{{cite web |url= http://www.dpmc.govt.nz/honours/lists/list.asp?id=21 |title=The Queen's Birthday Honours 1998 |date=1 June 1998 |publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet |accessdate=21 August 2011}} In November 2004, it was reported that Whineray was a top contender to replace Dame [[Silvia Cartwright]] as [[Governor-General of New Zealand|Governor-General]] in 2006.{{cite news |title=All Black top pick to be Governor-General |first=Audrey |last=Young |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3606240 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=2 November 2004 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} Bob Howitt has said that, "had he allowed his name to go forward, he would have become the Governor-General".{{cite news |title=Rugby legend finally spills the beans |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/rugby-legend-finally-spills-beans-3832685 |newspaper=One News |publisher=TVNZ |date=12 October 2010 |accessdate=12 March 2011}} He became the first New Zealander inducted into the [[IRB Hall of Fame]], being elected on 21 October 2007 (following the [[International Rugby Board|IRB]] World Cup in France) after a public vote.{{cite web |url= http://www.irb.com/history/halloffame/newsid=2027697.htm |title=2007 Inductee: Sir Wilson Whineray |date=1 December 2007 |publisher=International Rugby Board |accessdate=21 August 2011}} He died in Auckland in 2012, at the age of 77. ==All Blacks statistics== *Tests: 32 (30 as captain) *Games: 45 (37 as captain) *Total matches: 77 (67 as captain)
